A new, more affordable chip for mobile phones has been developed, promising to significantly reduce the cost of smartphones and potentially increase access to technology in developing countries.

The chip, developed by a team of engineers at the University of Cambridge, is said to be 40% cheaper to produce than current models. This could lead to a significant reduction in the retail price of smartphones, making them more accessible to a wider range of consumers.

The team used a novel manufacturing process that reduces the amount of silicon - a costly component of most chips - required. Instead, they used a cheaper, more abundant material, which they claim performs just as well.

"The new chip performs at a similar level to current chips, but at a fraction of the cost," said Dr. Robert Thompson, who led the research team. "This could be a game-changer in terms of making smartphones and other mobile technology more affordable and accessible."

The development could have significant implications for the global smartphone market, which is currently dominated by a small number of manufacturers. If the new chip can be produced at scale, it could disrupt the market and potentially lead to a wider range of companies producing affordable smartphones.

The team's findings have been published in the journal Nature Electronics, and they are now working with industry partners to explore the potential for commercial production.

The development could also have a significant impact in developing countries, where the high cost of smartphones can be a barrier to access. By making smartphones more affordable, the new chip could help to bridge the digital divide and enable more people to access the internet and digital services.

"This is not just about making cheaper smartphones," said Dr. Thompson. "It's about making technology more accessible and empowering people in developing countries to access digital services and opportunities."

The team is now working on further refining the chip and exploring other potential applications for their technology. They believe that their approach could also be used to reduce the cost of other types of electronic devices, potentially leading to a wider revolution in the electronics industry.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger has been given a significant financial boost ahead of the summer transfer window. The club's board has reportedly handed him a substantial 'war chest' to strengthen the squad for the upcoming season.

The Frenchman, who has been at the helm of the North London club for over two decades, is under pressure to deliver after a disappointing season. Arsenal finished outside the top four in the Premier League for the first time under Wenger's reign, leading to calls from some fans for a change in management.

However, the board has shown faith in Wenger, providing him with a significant budget to bring in new talent. The exact amount of the war chest has not been disclosed, but it is believed to be in the region of 150 million.

Wenger has been criticised in the past for his reluctance to spend big in the transfer market. However, this summer could see a change in strategy, with the manager already linked with several high-profile players.

Among the potential targets are Monaco's teenage sensation Kylian Mbappe, Lyon striker Alexandre Lacazette and Leicester City's Riyad Mahrez. Wenger is also reportedly keen on strengthening his defence, with Southampton's Virgil van Dijk and Juventus' Alex Sandro on his radar.

The Arsenal boss has previously stated that he is looking for "top, top quality" additions to his squad. With this war chest at his disposal, fans will be hoping that he can attract the calibre of players needed to challenge for the Premier League title next season.

However, Wenger will also need to focus on keeping his current stars at the club. Key players such as Alexis Sanchez and Mesut Ozil have been linked with moves away from the Emirates Stadium, and securing their futures will be a priority for the manager.

This summer promises to be a crucial one for Arsenal and Wenger. With a significant war chest to spend, the pressure is on to deliver a squad capable of challenging for major honours. Only time will tell if Wenger's summer spending spree can return Arsenal to the top of English football.

Former Prime Minister Tony Blair has expressed his readiness and enthusiasm ahead of the upcoming poll, stating that he is "up for it". This comes amidst speculation about his potential return to frontline politics.

Mr. Blair, who led the Labour Party to three consecutive general election victories, has been increasingly vocal about his views on the current political landscape. His recent comments have sparked rumours about his possible re-entry into the political arena.

In an interview with BBC, Mr. Blair said, "I am up for it. I think it's important that people who have experience and knowledge of how things work at the top level of government are involved in shaping the future of our country."

He added, "I believe that the challenges we face today - from climate change to the impact of technology on jobs - require experienced leadership. I am ready to contribute to the debate and, if necessary, to play a more direct role."

Mr. Blair's comments have been met with mixed reactions. Supporters argue that his experience and statesmanship are needed in these uncertain times. Critics, however, point to his controversial decision to support the Iraq War and question whether he is the right person to lead the country forward.

The former Prime Minister has not confirmed whether he intends to stand for election again. However, his comments suggest that he is seriously considering the possibility.

Mr. Blair's remarks come ahead of a crucial poll that could determine the direction of the Labour Party and the country. The poll, which is expected to be closely contested, will be a key test of the party's appeal to voters.

As the country prepares for the poll, Mr. Blair's comments have added an extra layer of intrigue to an already heated political climate. Whether or not he decides to return to frontline politics, his willingness to be involved signals a potentially significant shift in the UK's political landscape.

The Mayor of a small town in the UK has refused to retract a controversial comment he made, comparing a local policy to Nazi Germany. Despite facing significant backlash, the Mayor has stood by his remarks, stating that they were intended to highlight what he perceives as an overreach of authority.

The Mayor, whose identity has been withheld due to the sensitive nature of the issue, made the comment during a town council meeting last week. He compared a proposed local regulation, which would limit the number of pets residents can own, to the oppressive policies of Nazi Germany.

His remarks were met with immediate criticism from fellow council members and the public, many of whom called for an immediate apology. Critics argue that the comparison was not only inappropriate but also trivialised the atrocities committed during the Holocaust.

However, the Mayor has remained defiant, refusing to retract his statement. He argues that his comments were not intended to belittle the Holocaust but to draw attention to what he sees as an encroachment on personal freedoms.

"I stand by my comments," the Mayor said in a statement. "I did not mean to offend anyone, and I certainly did not mean to trivialise the Holocaust. My intention was to highlight what I see as an overreach of authority. I believe that the proposed regulation is an infringement on our personal freedoms."

The Mayor's refusal to retract his comments has sparked a heated debate within the community. Some residents support his stance, arguing that the proposed regulation is indeed an overreach of authority. Others, however, believe that his comments were insensitive and inappropriate.

The controversy has also attracted the attention of national media and prominent figures within the Jewish community. The Chief Rabbi has condemned the Mayor's comments, stating that "comparisons to Nazi Germany are always inappropriate and offensive, particularly when used in such a trivial context."

The local council is expected to discuss the matter further in a meeting next week. It remains to be seen whether the Mayor will face any disciplinary action for his comments.

Rugby legend Jonny Wilkinson has been named as the new head coach of the England rugby team, the Rugby Football Union (RFU) announced today. Wilkinson, who famously kicked the drop goal that won England the 2003 World Cup, will take over from Eddie Jones following the conclusion of the Six Nations tournament.

Wilkinson, 42, has been working as a skills coach with the England team since 2018, and his promotion to the top job marks a significant moment in his post-playing career. He is widely regarded as one of the greatest players in the history of English rugby, and his appointment has been met with widespread approval from players and fans alike.

RFU Chief Executive Bill Sweeney said in a statement: "Jonny is a true legend of the game and his success as a player for England speaks for itself. We believe he has the vision, the passion and the knowledge to lead England to future success."

Wilkinson's first task as head coach will be to prepare the team for their summer tour of Australia. He will be expected to build on the progress made under Jones, who led England to the final of the 2019 World Cup and two Six Nations titles during his tenure.

Speaking about his appointment, Wilkinson said: "I am incredibly honoured to be given this opportunity. I have always been passionate about English rugby and to be able to lead this team is a privilege. I am excited about the challenges ahead and look forward to working with the players and staff to continue to push this team forward."

Wilkinson's appointment comes at a time when English rugby is looking to rebuild after a disappointing Six Nations campaign. His experience and understanding of the game will be crucial as England look to re-establish themselves as one of the world's leading rugby nations.

Former England captain Lawrence Dallaglio described Wilkinson's appointment as a "fantastic move" for English rugby. "Jonny has a deep understanding of the game and what it takes to succeed at the highest level," he said. "I have no doubt he will bring the same dedication and commitment to his coaching role as he did as a player."

Wilkinson's tenure as England head coach will officially begin on 1 July, following the conclusion of the Six Nations tournament.

Former Arsenal boss Arsene Wenger has escalated a row with his critics, doubling down on the views that led to fierce scrutinizing of his final years in charge of the prestigious club.

Wenger, who left the Gunners in 2018 after 22 years in charge, told BBC Sport he absolutely stands by his decisions, which aimed to balance the club's financial health and on-pitch success.

The 71-year-old Frenchman's stance has increasingly attracted criticism as Arsenal has struggled to keep pace with Englands elite in recent years. Wenger's latter years were marred by fan protests and unrest over the perceived lack of investment in players.

However, Wenger defended his position and his association with the club's board, who, he says, were not ready to throw money at the problem. "I think I worked in a very honest and brave way," he said adding, "It was important to make sure the club was safe for the future."

He also took a swipe at critics who, he says, are rushing to judge his successor Mikel Arteta despite the team's recent poor performances. "In our job, you can look in two directions - the future and the day," Wenger said. "People are always more focused on the day and it creates a lot of controversies and impatience."

The legacy of Wenger at Arsenal remains a talking point, with fans divided over the club's direction under his stewardship. However, Wenger insisted that his guiding principle had been what was best for Arsenal in the long run. 

Despite his controversial tenure, Wenger said he never thought about quitting Arsenal. "I believe myself to be a fighter in my whole life; I've had to fight a lot to get what I wanted," he said. "I've never considered giving up that fight." 

Regardless of the current row, Wenger's contribution to English football is undeniable, leading Arsenal to three Premier League titles and seven FA Cups, and overseeing the 'Invincibles' season in 2003-04 when the team went unbeaten in the league. However, his defence of his latter years at the helm continues to fuel the controversy and spark debate amongst English football fans and pundits.

Whether Arsenal will find success after Wenger's reign, or whether the Frenchman's critics will be proven correct in their critiques, remains to be seen. Until then, the debate surrounding Wenger's final years at Arsenal, it seems, will continue to rage on.

General Motors (GM), the world's largest carmaker, has issued a warning that its profits for 2005 will be significantly lower than previously forecasted. The Detroit-based company has attributed this to a slump in sales in North America and increased healthcare costs.

GM now expects to make $1-$2 per share in 2005, down from its previous estimate of $4-$5. This news has led to a sharp fall in the company's shares, which dropped by 14% on the New York Stock Exchange.

The company's North American operations have been hit hard by a decline in the sales of sports utility vehicles (SUVs), one of GM's most profitable product lines. The fall in sales is believed to be due to high petrol prices and increased competition from foreign carmakers.

In addition to the decline in sales, GM is also grappling with rising healthcare costs for its US workforce. The company is one of the largest private providers of health care in the US, and these costs have been a significant drain on its finances.

GM's chairman and chief executive, Rick Wagoner, described 2005 as "one of the most challenging years in GM's history". He added that the company was "not standing still" and was taking "tough but necessary actions" to address its problems.

These actions include a plan to cut 30,000 jobs and close several plants in North America over the next few years. GM is also in talks with the United Auto Workers union about ways to reduce healthcare costs.

Despite the gloomy forecast for 2005, Mr. Wagoner remains optimistic about the company's future. He said that GM was "aggressively implementing" its turnaround plan and was "committed to turning our North American business around".

However, some analysts are sceptical about GM's ability to recover quickly. They argue that the company's problems are deep-rooted and will take time to fix. They also point out that GM is facing stiff competition from Asian carmakers, who are gaining market share in the US.

The profit warning from GM is the latest in a series of setbacks for the company. Last year, it lost its status as the world's largest carmaker to Toyota, and it has been struggling with a series of accounting scandals and lawsuits.

The United Kingdom has emerged as the world's biggest music buyer, according to a recent report by the International Federation of the Phonographic Industry (IFPI). The study reveals that the UK music industry is now worth an estimated 1.33 billion, surpassing the United States, which has traditionally held the top spot.

The report attributes this surge to the growing popularity of streaming services such as Spotify, Apple Music, and Amazon Music. The UK's digital music consumption has seen a significant increase, with 91% of the population now listening to music online.

The IFPI's report also highlights the UK's contribution to the global music scene, with British artists accounting for one in every eight albums sold worldwide. This is a testament to the global appeal of UK artists, from established acts like Ed Sheeran and Adele to emerging talents like Dua Lipa and Stormzy.

Frances Moore, Chief Executive of IFPI, said: "The UK is a global music powerhouse. The results of this report are a testament to the outstanding creativity of our artists, the resilience of our industry and the passion of music fans."

The report also indicates a shift in the way music is consumed. Physical sales have continued to decline, while digital sales and streaming have seen a significant increase. This trend is expected to continue, with streaming predicted to account for over half of all music consumption by 2023.

The UK government has recognised the importance of the music industry to the economy and has pledged to support its growth. The Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport has announced a 1.57 billion recovery fund to help the music industry recover from the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic.

The UK's position as the world's biggest music buyer is a significant achievement and reflects the nation's love for music. It also highlights the importance of the music industry to the UK economy and the need for continued investment and support.

However, despite the UK's success, the report also warns of the challenges facing the music industry. These include the need to ensure fair remuneration for artists and the impact of Brexit on the industry's ability to tour and trade freely.

The UK's music industry has shown remarkable resilience and adaptability in the face of these challenges. With continued support and investment, it is well-positioned to maintain its status as the world's biggest music buyer and continue its significant contribution to the global music scene.

Former Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard has sought to temper expectations about his team's chances in the upcoming European football season. The Rangers manager, who has been at the helm since 2018, has been instrumental in the club's recent domestic success, but believes that a European triumph may be a step too far at this stage.

Gerrard, who famously led Liverpool to a Champions League victory in 2005, has been realistic about the challenges his team faces in the European arena. "We've got a good squad, but we're up against some top-quality opposition," he said in a press conference. "We'll give it our best shot, but we need to be realistic about our chances."

Rangers have enjoyed a resurgence under Gerrard's leadership, winning the Scottish Premiership last season for the first time in a decade. However, the European stage presents a different level of competition, with teams like Paris Saint-Germain, Manchester City, and Bayern Munich boasting world-class talent.

Gerrard's comments come ahead of Rangers' opening group stage match in the Europa League against Lyon. The French side, who reached the semi-finals of the Champions League in 2020, are considered one of the favourites to win the competition.

Despite playing down his team's chances, Gerrard insisted that Rangers would not be overawed by the occasion. "We're not here to make up the numbers," he said. "We'll approach every game with the belief that we can get a result."

The former England international also highlighted the importance of the club's supporters in their European campaign. "Our fans have been fantastic and their support will be crucial for us," he said. "We'll need them every step of the way."

While Gerrard's realism may dampen some fans' expectations, it also underlines the scale of the task facing Rangers in Europe. The club's domestic success has raised hopes of a strong showing in the Europa League, but Gerrard's comments serve as a reminder of the challenges that lie ahead.

A recent report revealing a startling upsurge in custody deaths in the United Kingdom has left Members of Parliament deeply shocked and concerned. Members from all political parties are calling for urgent investigations and reforms to halt this unsettling trend.

In the last year alone, recorded deaths in police custody, prisons, and immigration detention centres across the UK have spiked alarmingly. Detailed figures show that the number of deaths has increased by 25% compared to the previous year. These figures include instances of suicide, natural causes, and deaths under investigation concerning potentially inappropriate or negligent conduct.

Mps across the aisles have expressed their astonishment and deep concern over these alarming figures. Labour MP Yvette Cooper, the chair of the Home Affairs Select Committee, tweeted "Disturbing increase in deaths in custody - immediate action needed. The figures raise urgent questions about the support being provided."

Conservative MP Sir Peter Bottomley echoed Cooper's sentiments, stating, "The death of any individual in custody is a cause for concern, let alone such a dramatic surge. These devastating statistics require urgent review and attention."

Recent high-profile cases of alleged police negligence resulting in the deaths of individuals like Brian Ringrose and Leroy Junior Medford have further drawn the publics attention to this, already volatile issue. Family members of these victims were present later in Parliament, urging for changes in the system.

Questions are being raised about police use of force, training, and whether appropriate mental health assessments and support are being provided to vulnerable detainees. It is believed that a significant proportion of the individuals who died in custody struggled with mental health issues or addiction  problems inadequately addressed in the current custodial system.

Campaigners advocating for prisoners' rights have also voiced their dismay, pointing out a stark deterioration in the prison service. Frances Crook, CEO of the Howard League for Penal Reform, called it, "An indication of a system in crisis, where basic humanity has been compromised."

In response to the outcry, the Minister for Crime and Policing, Kit Malthouse MP, promised a review of the concerning data. "It is vital that every individual in custody is treated humanely and fairly," he stated. "We are committed to reducing custody deaths, ensuring the safety of detainees, and maintaining trust and confidence in our justice system."

As Parliament gears up to deal with this escalating crisis, the wider public is calling for immediate transparency, accountability, and reform in the system. The need for decisive solutions and a balanced approach that guarantees public safety while upholding human rights is felt more deeply than ever before

The festive season has seen a surge in box office numbers, with the comedy sequel "Little Fockers" leading the pack. The film, which is the third installment in the "Meet the Parents" series, has topped the UK and Ireland box office chart over the Christmas period.

"Little Fockers", starring Ben Stiller, Robert De Niro and Owen Wilson, raked in 3.1m between Boxing Day and New Year's Eve, according to film industry analysts. The film's success is a testament to the enduring popularity of the franchise, which began with "Meet the Parents" in 2000 and continued with "Meet the Fockers" in 2004.

The film's plot revolves around the comedic trials and tribulations of Greg Focker (Stiller) as he navigates the challenges of parenthood and dealing with his overbearing father-in-law, played by De Niro. The film's light-hearted and family-friendly humour seems to have struck a chord with audiences looking for some festive cheer.

In second place on the chart was the latest installment of the "Narnia" series, "The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader", which took 1.8m. The film, based on the beloved children's books by C.S. Lewis, has been a consistent performer since its release in early December.

Rounding out the top three was Disney's "Tangled", a retelling of the Rapunzel fairy tale, which earned 1.3m. The animated film has been praised for its stunning visuals and engaging storytelling, appealing to both children and adults alike.

The festive period is traditionally a strong time for the film industry, with families flocking to cinemas for some holiday entertainment. This year's chart shows a diverse range of films succeeding, from comedy sequels to fantasy adventures and animated tales.

As we move into the new year, it remains to be seen whether "Little Fockers" can maintain its lead, or if a new contender will rise to the top of the box office chart. Regardless, it's clear that the Fockers have once again proven to be a hit with audiences, providing plenty of laughs and festive fun.

Tensions have escalated between the major political parties as they clash over tax and spending plans ahead of the upcoming general election. The Conservatives and Labour have both unveiled their fiscal strategies, sparking a fierce debate about the future of the UK economy.

The Conservative party has pledged to freeze income tax, VAT and national insurance contributions, arguing that this will help hard-working families and stimulate economic growth. They have also promised to increase public spending on health and education, while maintaining a commitment to fiscal prudence.

Labour, on the other hand, has proposed a more radical approach, promising to increase taxes on the wealthiest in society and large corporations. They argue that this will generate additional revenue to fund public services and reduce inequality. However, critics have questioned whether these measures would deter investment and potentially damage the economy.

The Liberal Democrats have also entered the fray, proposing a balanced approach that includes modest tax increases for high earners and additional spending on key public services. They argue that their plan is the most sustainable and fair, and would help to protect the economy while also improving public services.

The Green Party, meanwhile, has proposed the most radical changes, including a wealth tax, a financial transaction tax, and significant increases in public spending. They argue that these measures are necessary to address inequality and fund the transition to a green economy.

The SNP has focused its campaign on opposing austerity and advocating for increased public spending in Scotland. They argue that the other parties' plans do not go far enough in addressing the needs of the Scottish people.

The pre-poll clash on tax and spend has highlighted the stark choices facing voters in the upcoming election. While all parties agree on the need to invest in public services, there is significant disagreement about how to fund these investments and the potential impact on the economy.

Economists have warned that the UK's economic outlook is uncertain, with Brexit and global trade tensions posing significant risks. They argue that the next government will need to strike a careful balance between stimulating growth, maintaining fiscal discipline, and investing in public services.

As the election campaign enters its final weeks, the debate over tax and spend is set to intensify. With the polls suggesting a close race, the parties' fiscal plans could play a crucial role in determining the outcome.

Campaigners pressurising the UK Government to extend the Border's railway link from Tweedbank to Carlisle have organised an enthusiastic public rally to accentuate their point. Their aim is to reconnect communities in the Scottish Borders with the rail network in England. 

The event held at Galashiels Transport Interchange drew large crowds, many of whom support the extensive campaign labeled "Destination Carlisle". Veterans of the original Save the Border Rail Campaign were in attendance, who fought for the reinstatement of the Edinburgh-Tweedbank railway line that was officially reopened in 2015.

The Campaign for Borders Rail (CBR) is optimistic about the potential for socio-economic upliftment in the region with the inclusion of a direct rail link. The journey between the two cities, at about 58 miles, currently requires a car or bus. 

CBR spokesperson, Jess Granger, voiced her enthusiasm at the rally, stating "It's a pleasure to see such a fantastic turnout at the rally. It underscores the passion and desire of the Borders community to see the rail link restored. This is more than just about transportation. It's about integration, growth, community development, and forging closer ties with our English neighbors."

Moreover, David Parker, former leader of the Scottish Borders council and a long time campaigner stated, "We need to keep the pressure on all levels of government to see this project realised. It's essential for strengthening the local economy through improved access to jobs and educational opportunities."

Additionally, the campaign has devised an online petition, garnering over 10,000 signatures thus far. Their efforts aim to convince the UK government of the lasting benefits that the rail link can offer.

Politics aside, the extension could be a crucial opportunity for Scotland and England to become more interconnected, creating a quicker, more sustainable method of transport between the regions.

 An economic impact study, conducted by the Scottish Border council into the proposed extension, expect its findings to be published later this year. This evidence could potentially boost the case for a new rail link, substantiating the socio-economic benefits the campaigners believe it will bring. 

Transport Scotland, the national transport agency, expressed that they are aware of the campaign and eagerly await the economic impact study's results. 

Nonetheless, it is clear the Borders community is rallying together to achieve a common goal, and their united front will surely make it hard for their voices to be ignored.

Returning to Europes top-tier football competition this year might still be a pipedream for Rangers FC, as their manager, Steven Gerrard, refuses to let high expectations get the better of the team's steady progress this season. 

The Scottish Premiership leaders have been awarded plaudits for their remarkable domestic form this season, making waves and raising hopes for European qualification in the process. However, in a recent press conference, Gerrard made it clear that staying grounded remains the primary goal. 

Our focus is on the Scottish Premiership, and ensuring we stay consistent through the season, Gerrard stated. Europe is definitely an aspiration; the dream for any club at this level. But to say were within reach is to overstate our situation.

This caution shouldn't be misconstrued for a lack of ambition from the former Liverpool stalwart. Gerrard is acutely aware of the impact a European top-tier berth would have on the club and its fans, but he refuses to let this dilute their domestic focus. 

We have worked very hard to instil a strong mentality within the squad, and complacency can undo much of that good work. As much as we are hopeful, and as much as we want it, we will not let aspirations for Europe distract us from our domestic duties, Gerrard added.

Under Gerrard's guidance, Rangers have made significant strides. Their current league form is undeniably their best since their return to top flight football, but the manager is adamant that nothing should compromise their domestic stability. 

The former England international concedes that every upturn in form naturally comes with heightened expectations, but he remains resolute in his methodical approach. Our fans have been tremendous, and one of the most gratifying aspects of our current form has been seeing their excitement. But we owe it to them to maintain a realistic perspective. Theres still plenty of football to be played, both domestically and in Europe."

It's crystal clear that Gerrard is refusing to count his chickens before they hatch. While he acknowledges that the prospect of competing in Europe is an exciting one, he is firm in his focus on the Scottish Premiership above all else. A stance that reflects his realistic approach, and one that serves as a sobering reminder to players and fans alike that the journey to success is a long and challenging one.

France Telecom, the leading telecommunications company in France, has received a significant boost from its subsidiary, Orange. This comes as a welcome relief for the telecom giant, which has been grappling with a challenging market environment.

Orange, the mobile and internet services arm of France Telecom, has reported robust growth in its latest financial results. The company's strong performance has been attributed to its successful strategies in customer acquisition and retention, as well as its continuous investment in network infrastructure and digital innovation.

The positive results from Orange have provided a much-needed uplift for France Telecom, which has been facing stiff competition from other telecom providers. The company has been struggling with declining revenues and profitability in recent years, due to factors such as market saturation, regulatory pressures, and the rapid pace of technological change.

The boost from Orange has helped to offset some of these challenges, providing a bright spot in France Telecom's overall financial picture. The subsidiary's strong performance has also underscored its strategic importance to the parent company, reinforcing its role as a key driver of growth and profitability.

Orange's success has been driven by a number of factors, including its focus on customer service, its competitive pricing strategies, and its ongoing investment in new technologies and services. The company has also benefited from the strong demand for mobile and internet services, both in France and in other markets where it operates.

The boost from Orange comes at a critical time for France Telecom, as the company seeks to navigate a complex and rapidly evolving market landscape. The positive results from the subsidiary provide a much-needed source of optimism, offering a clear indication that the company's strategic initiatives are starting to bear fruit.

Moving forward, France Telecom will be looking to build on the momentum generated by Orange, with a focus on driving further growth and improving its competitive position. The company will also continue to invest in digital innovation, as it seeks to stay ahead of the curve in a fast-paced and dynamic industry.

In conclusion, the boost from Orange represents a significant positive development for France Telecom. It not only provides a welcome uplift in the company's financial performance, but also underscores the strategic importance of the subsidiary in driving growth and profitability.

Mobile phones, the ubiquitous devices that have revolutionised communication, have now been in use for two decades, marking a significant milestone in the history of technology. 

The first mobile phone call was made on 3rd April 1973, but it wasn't until the 1990s that mobile phones became widely available and affordable for the general public. Since then, they have evolved from bulky, expensive devices with limited functionality to sleek, powerful gadgets that are an integral part of our daily lives.

Over the past 20 years, mobile phones have transformed the way we communicate, work, and entertain ourselves. They have made it possible to stay connected with people around the world, access information at our fingertips, and capture and share moments in real-time.

The evolution of mobile phones has been driven by advances in technology and changing consumer demands. The introduction of smartphones in the late 2000s marked a significant shift, turning mobile phones into multi-purpose devices that can be used for browsing the internet, sending emails, playing games, and much more.

The rise of mobile phones has also had a profound impact on various industries. For instance, they have disrupted the traditional media industry by enabling the rise of social media and streaming services. They have also transformed the retail industry by facilitating online shopping and mobile payments.

Despite the numerous benefits, the widespread use of mobile phones has also raised concerns about privacy, security, and the impact on mental health. There are ongoing debates about the need for regulation to address these issues.

As mobile phones celebrate 20 years of use, it's clear that they have become an indispensable part of our lives. Looking ahead, it's exciting to imagine what the next 20 years might bring. With advancements in technologies like 5G, artificial intelligence, and virtual reality, the future of mobile phones looks promising.

In the meantime, as we mark this milestone, it's worth reflecting on how far we've come and the incredible impact that these small devices have had on our lives. From the first call made on a brick-like device to the latest smartphone in our pocket, the journey of mobile phones over the past 20 years is truly remarkable.

UK supermarket giant, Sainsbury's, has made a significant contribution to the Labour Party's election campaign, marking a notable shift in the political landscape. The donation, which is believed to be in the region of six figures, is one of the largest the party has received from a corporate entity in recent years.

The move is seen as a significant endorsement of the Labour Party's economic policies, which have been criticised by some business leaders for being too left-wing. However, Sainsbury's decision to back the party suggests that there is growing confidence in the business community about Labour's plans for the economy.

A spokesperson for Sainsbury's confirmed the donation, stating: "We believe in a fair and balanced economy and feel that the Labour Party's policies align with our own values. We are proud to support them in the upcoming election."

The Labour Party has welcomed the donation, with a spokesperson saying: "This generous donation from Sainsbury's is a clear endorsement of our economic policies. It shows that businesses, both big and small, are beginning to recognise that a Labour government would be good for the economy."

The donation comes at a crucial time for the Labour Party, which has been struggling to match the Conservative Party's fundraising efforts. The Conservatives have traditionally enjoyed strong support from the business community, but this latest donation suggests that the tide may be turning.

Political analysts suggest that Sainsbury's donation could encourage other businesses to follow suit. "This is a significant moment," said Professor David Cutts, a political scientist at the University of Birmingham. "If other businesses see that a company as big and respected as Sainsbury's is backing Labour, they might feel more confident about doing the same."

However, the Conservatives have dismissed the significance of the donation. A party spokesperson said: "We are confident that our policies are the ones that will deliver for businesses and for the economy. One donation does not change that."

The Labour Party will be hoping that Sainsbury's donation will give them a much-needed boost in the polls, as they seek to close the gap on the Conservatives ahead of the election.

US car giants General Motors (GM) and Ford have announced significant cuts in production due to a sharp decline in sales, reflecting the ongoing impact of the global chip shortage and the pandemic on the auto industry.

General Motors, the largest US automaker, said it would reduce production at most of its North American plants for two weeks because of the ongoing semiconductor chip shortage. The company did not disclose how much volume it would lose or which suppliers were causing the largest issues.

Meanwhile, Ford, the second-largest US automaker, also announced that it would temporarily halt production at its Kansas City assembly plant, which makes its best-selling F-150 pickup truck, due to the chip shortage. The company also said it would cut shifts at two more of its plants.

The global chip shortage has hit automakers particularly hard, causing delays in production and forcing some to temporarily close factories. The problem was exacerbated by a fire at a key chip plant in Japan and severe winter weather in Texas, where a large number of chipmakers have factories.

The production cuts come as both GM and Ford are grappling with a significant drop in sales. According to the latest data, GM's sales fell by 6.4% in the first quarter of 2021 compared to the same period last year, while Ford's sales dropped by 14.1%.

Both companies have warned that the chip shortage and the production cuts will significantly impact their profits. GM said it could shave up to $2bn off its earnings this year, while Ford warned it could hit its profits by as much as $2.5bn.

The auto industry is a key part of the US economy, and the production cuts could have wider implications, potentially leading to job losses and a slowdown in economic recovery.

The chip shortage is expected to last into 2022, according to industry experts, adding to the challenges facing the auto industry as it tries to recover from the impact of the pandemic.

Swiss cement giant, LafargeHolcim, has embarked on a significant acquisition spree, snapping up several companies in a bid to expand its global footprint. The move comes as the company seeks to capitalise on the booming construction industry and strengthen its position as a leading supplier of building materials.

In a series of deals announced over the past few weeks, LafargeHolcim has acquired a number of smaller firms across Europe, Asia, and North America. The acquisitions include a majority stake in a German cement company, a Chinese concrete firm, and a Canadian aggregates business.

The company's aggressive expansion strategy is seen as a response to the growing demand for construction materials, driven by a global surge in infrastructure projects and residential construction. The acquisitions are expected to significantly boost LafargeHolcim's production capacity and market share.

CEO of LafargeHolcim, Jan Jenisch, said: "These acquisitions are an important part of our growth strategy. They will allow us to better serve our customers by providing a wider range of products and services, and to expand our presence in key markets."

The Swiss firm's buying spree has been largely financed by its strong cash flow and robust balance sheet, which has been bolstered by a series of cost-cutting measures and efficiency improvements implemented over the past few years.

However, the acquisitions have also raised concerns about potential anti-competitive behaviour. Some industry observers have warned that LafargeHolcim's growing dominance could lead to higher prices and less choice for consumers.

In response to these concerns, Jenisch said: "We are committed to fair competition. We believe that our acquisitions will benefit customers by providing them with better products and services, and we will continue to work closely with regulators to ensure that our business practices are in line with competition laws."

Despite these assurances, the company's acquisition spree is likely to face scrutiny from competition authorities in the countries where the acquired firms are based.

LafargeHolcim is the world's largest cement manufacturer, with operations in more than 70 countries. The company was formed in 2015 through the merger of French firm Lafarge and Swiss company Holcim, and has since become a major player in the global construction industry.

The UK's sport betting industry is under scrutiny as questions are raised about the current betting rules and regulations amid increasing concern over gambling addiction and related harm.

The Gambling Act 2005, which currently governs how betting, sports, bingo, casino games and lottery draws are run in the UK, is due for review, with increased focus on the sports betting arena. This review comes against a backdrop of mounting public concern about the effects of gambling on vulnerable individuals and communities.

One of the main areas for consideration is the role of advertising in local sports. Critics argue that relationships between sports teams and betting companies can encourage problem gambling. The integration of betting advertisements within sports broadcasts is also a contentious issue that will be addressed.

Over the past decade, the betting landscape has dramatically shifted with the advent of online gambling. This uptick has seen a rise in cases of gambling addiction, prompting calls for tighter controls over online bookmakers and gambling companies. According to the Gambling Commission, 55,000 children aged 11 to 16 have a gambling problem, a figure that has quadrupled in the past two years.

During the review, a prominent concern will be whether betting companies are doing enough to safeguard young people and limit their exposure to gambling advertisements. The Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport (DCMS) will scrutinise existing legislation to ensure it is fit for the digital age.

Some stakeholders have called for a complete overhaul of the sports betting rules. The All Party Parliamentary Group on Gambling Related Harm has suggested drastic measures such as a blanket ban on gambling advertising and setting limits on betting.

Many soccer teams in the UK count betting firms among their main sponsors, who they rely on for significant financial support. Therefore, any rule changes could have considerable implications for these teams, sparking intense debate among stakeholders in both the sports and betting worlds.

At the same time, sport betting providers argue that current regulations are sufficient and it is the enforcement that needs to be toughened up.

Legislators, health bodies, and sporting organisations have acknowledged that a balance must be struck between the economic benefits brought by the gambling industry and the need to protect the most vulnerable from harm.

The government review into the Gambling Act 2005, spearheaded by the DCMS alongside the Advisory Board for Safer Gambling, is expected to publish its findings and recommendations by the end of the year.

While the outcome of this spotlight on sports betting rules remains uncertain, it is clear that this is a pivotal moment for the future of the UKs sport betting industry. Whether the rules change or

Former Chelsea and Arsenal defender, William Gallas, has predicted that the Premier League race this season is likely to come down to two teams - Manchester City and Liverpool.

The experienced Frenchman, who played for Chelsea and Arsenal between 2001 and 2010, stated this during his recent interview with a popular sports channel. He believes that the superiority of these two teams in recent seasons, coupled with their formidable squads, positions them as front runners for the 2021-2022 Premier League title.

Gallas, who won two Premier League titles during his time at Chelsea, said: "I believe this season will be between City and Liverpool. They have been very strong for the last few years, and I think they will be again this year. They have the best squads and the best managers, so for me, it's between those two."

Manchester City, managed by Pep Guardiola, won the domestic title last season, finishing 12 points clear at the top of the table, while Jurgen Klopp's Liverpool side were the champions in the 2019-2020 season.

The comments from Gallas set up an exciting narrative for the new season, adding more fuel to the already blazing competition. However, he did not completely rule out other contenders, specifically mentioning his former club Chelsea under the leadership of Thomas Tuchel, and Manchester United with their new signing, Jadon Sancho.

"Of course, you cannot discount Chelsea or Manchester United. They have been signing some very good players. Chelsea have a good coach in Tuchel, and Man Utd have now added Sancho. They will be dangerous, definitely, but I still see City and Liverpool as the main contenders," Gallas added.

The Premier League season kicked off on August 13, with the intensity and competition set to ratchet up over the coming months. Fans worldwide will be keen to see if Gallas' prediction comes true or if there's a surprise waiting down the line.

Former Liverpool manager, Rafael Benitez, has issued a stern warning to Steven Gerrard, as the latter prepares to take over the reins at Aston Villa. Benitez, who managed Gerrard during his successful stint at Liverpool, has cautioned the former England captain about the challenges of Premier League management.

Gerrard, who recently left his role as Rangers manager to take up the Aston Villa job, is set to embark on his first managerial stint in the Premier League. Benitez, currently managing Everton, has offered some words of advice to his former player.

"Managing in the Premier League is a different ball game," Benitez said. "The pressure, the expectations, and the level of competition are all much higher. Steven has done a fantastic job at Rangers, but he must be prepared for a different kind of challenge at Aston Villa."

Benitez, who won the Champions League with Liverpool in 2005 with Gerrard as his captain, also highlighted the importance of having a good support system in place. "It's crucial to have a strong team around you. You need people who understand the game, who can offer advice and support when things get tough," he added.

The Spanish manager also warned Gerrard about the high expectations that come with managing a Premier League club. "Aston Villa is a big club with a rich history. The fans will expect results and performances. Steven must be ready to deliver on those expectations," Benitez said.

Gerrard, who won the Scottish Premiership title with Rangers last season, will be hoping to replicate his success in England. However, with Benitez's warning, it's clear that the former Liverpool captain has a tough task ahead.

Benitez concluded his advice by wishing Gerrard well in his new role. "I wish Steven all the best at Aston Villa. He was a fantastic player and has shown he can be a great manager. I'm sure he'll do well, but he must be prepared for the challenges that lie ahead."

Gerrard's first game in charge of Aston Villa will be against Brighton on November 20th. It remains to be seen how he will fare in the Premier League, but with advice from seasoned managers like Benitez, Gerrard will surely be better prepared for the task ahead.

Former UK Prime Minister Tony Blair has praised the agreement reached to initiate talks between Turkey and the European Union (EU), describing it as a "historic moment". 

Mr Blair, who has been a long-standing advocate for Turkey's EU membership, said the decision to start negotiations was a "huge achievement" and a "win-win" for both sides. He added that Turkey's accession to the EU would be a "powerful symbol" of the union's commitment to diversity and inclusivity.

The decision to start talks was reached after intense negotiations, with Austria dropping its objections after the EU agreed to include a reference to "privileged partnership" as an alternative to full membership. The talks are expected to last for at least a decade and will cover a wide range of issues, including human rights, economic reforms and Cyprus.

Mr Blair said: "This is a historic moment for Turkey and for Europe. It shows that the EU is a truly inclusive organisation, open to all countries that share its values and are willing to abide by its rules."

He added: "Turkey's accession would be a powerful symbol of the EU's commitment to diversity and inclusivity. It would show that the EU is not a Christian club, but a union of nations committed to democracy, human rights and the rule of law."

The former Prime Minister also highlighted the economic benefits of Turkey's membership, saying it would create new opportunities for trade and investment. He said: "Turkey is a dynamic, fast-growing economy. Its membership would bring new energy and vitality to the EU."

However, Mr Blair acknowledged that the negotiations would be "long and difficult", and that Turkey would need to make "significant reforms" to meet the EU's membership criteria. He said: "This is the start of a long journey. But I am confident that Turkey is ready to take on this challenge."

The decision to start talks with Turkey has been controversial, with some EU member states expressing concerns about the country's human rights record, its treatment of the Kurdish minority, and its refusal to recognise Cyprus, an EU member state. However, Mr Blair said these issues would be addressed during the negotiations.

He concluded: "This is a historic opportunity for Turkey and for Europe. We should seize it with both hands."

The UK property market is experiencing a slowdown, according to a recent survey conducted by the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS). The survey, which included responses from estate agents and surveyors across the country, revealed a significant drop in the number of people looking to buy a home and a decrease in property prices.

RICS reported that the net balance of surveyors seeing a rise in buyer enquiries fell to -15% in August, down from -7% in July. This is the lowest level since May 2020, when the country was in the midst of the first national lockdown due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

The survey also found that the net balance of surveyors reporting house price increases fell to +46% in August, down from +52% in July. This indicates a slowdown in the rate of house price growth, although prices are still rising overall.

RICS attributed the slowdown to a combination of factors, including the end of the stamp duty holiday and the ongoing economic uncertainty caused by the pandemic. The institution also noted that the supply of properties for sale remains limited, which could be contributing to the slowdown in buyer activity.

"The market is starting to lose some steam with both demand from potential buyers and sales starting to slip back," said Simon Rubinsohn, RICS Chief Economist. "However, with the supply of properties for sale remaining tight, it's likely that prices will continue to rise in the short term."

The survey's findings are in line with other recent reports suggesting a slowdown in the UK property market. Last month, the Nationwide Building Society reported that house price growth had slowed to its lowest level in six months, while the Bank of England reported a drop in mortgage approvals.

Despite the slowdown, RICS noted that surveyors remain relatively optimistic about the market's prospects over the next 12 months. The net balance of surveyors expecting house prices to rise over the next year stood at +30% in August, down slightly from +33% in July.

However, Rubinsohn warned that the market could face further challenges in the coming months, particularly if the economic impact of the pandemic worsens. "The big question is what happens next," he said. "With the furlough scheme coming to an end and job uncertainty rising, the outlook for the housing market is very much up in the air."

Former England Under-21 boss Stuart Pearce has expressed strong interest in succeeding Kevin Keegan as the permanent manager of Newcastle United. Keegan stepped down from the coveted position earlier this month due to disagreements with the club's hierarchy over player signings. Pearce, who guided the England Under-21 team to the final of the 2009 UEFA European Under-21 Championship, said he is ready for a new challenge in his career.

Pearce spent two years as manager of Manchester City before being sacked in 2007. Since then, he has gained significant experience working with young players as the head coach of England Under-21s. During that time, he successfully led the team to the Under-21 European Championships final in 2009 and semi-finals in 2007.

Speaking to reporters, Pearce said, "I've always maintained that my future lies in club management and the vacancy at Newcastle United represents a fantastic opportunity. It's a club with great tradition, passionate fans and a talented squad of players."

He expressed his admiration for Keegan, saying, "Kevin did an incredible job whilst in charge of Newcastle, however the game moves on and now the focus is to build on his legacy." 

Reacting to the news, former Newcastle United striker Alan Shearer said, "Stuart is a determined, ambitious coach with a strong mentality. I believe he could be the right leader for Newcastle at this critical time."

Pearce's interest in the role comes as Newcastle United has already began the search for a new manager, a process they admit might not be swift. Names such as former Lyon boss Bruno Genesio and ex-Arsenal manager Arsne Wenger have also been mooted as potential candidates for the role.

Newcastle United are currently 14th in the Premier League, having won only one of their first four games of the season. Pearce, if appointed, would be tasked with improving the team's performances and hauling them up the table.

Earlier this year, Pearce expressed his desire to go back into full-time management after enjoying his time in coaching duties with the England national team.

No official comment from Newcastle United regarding Pearce's statement has been made public yet.

Former Liverpool and Leeds United winger, Harry Kewell, remains sideline amidst long-standing injury concerns. The Australian football legend's return to the field continues being delayed, casting a shadow over his highly anticipated comeback.

Kewell, now 39, who also had a distinguished international career with the Socceroos, has been suffering from a gruelling lingering injury, the nature of which hasn't been disclosed. His long-awaited return to the field has now been put on hold indefinitely.

The stalwart, who was at the peak of his career in the early 2000s, has been diligently working on his recovery, undergoing rigorous rehabilitation programmes. However, despite his disciplined efforts, his injury is taking longer than expected to heal, leaving fans and followers in continued suspense.

Kewell's spokesperson earlier spoke with the press, stating, "Harry is understandably disappointed with the delay. He's, however, committed to returning to the field in pristine condition and won't rush his recovery process risking further complications."

The Australian's last competitive match came for Melbourne Heart, where he retired in 2014. Last year, he had hinted at making a surprise return to action, generating widespread enthusiasm amongst his followers. The current setback, however, has resulted in dampened spirits for those hoping to see the ex-Galatasaray player back in action.

Medical experts suggest the type of injury Kewell has suffered usually requires a momentous healing period, and a rush to return could potentially lead to long-term problems. Meanwhile, Kewell's unwavering commitment to his recovery and his passion for football remains his driving force.

The delay in Kewell's return has sparked a conversation in the sports industry about player's health, safety protocols, and the demanding nature of professional football. It is a potent reminder of the physical demands intrinsic to this globally followed sport.

In the meantime, fans and followers worldwide wait with bated breath for further updates about Kewell's recovery. Despite the setback, optimism remains high for Kewell's return to football, and his fans continue to rally in support.

British MP George Galloway has issued an urgent plea calling for the release of a UK citizen taken captive in the Middle East. The statement comes amid increasing fears for the hostages safety. 

In his appeal, the veteran MP said he was deeply concerned about the individual, whose identity is being protected for security reasons. While no specific group has claimed responsibility for the abduction, it is widely believed that the hostage is in the hands of a militant group operating in the region.

"The kidnap and detention of innocent civilians is a flagrant violation of international law. It is an act of barbarity that undermines efforts to bring peace and stability to this troubled region," said Mr. Galloway. "We urge those holding the hostage to release him immediately, unconditionally, and safely."

The plight of the kidnapped individual, reportedly an aid worker, has been shrouded in secrecy due to fears that publicity could put him at further risk. It is understood that the UK Foreign Office is working behind the scenes, alongside international partners, to secure his release. 

As a long-standing critic of Western involvement in the Middle East, George Galloway has previously used his influence to call for the protection of civilians caught in conflict zones. His plea adds to a chorus of voices globally calling for the swift and safe return of the kidnapped aid worker.

The Foreign and Commonwealth Office has confirmed the kidnapping, but declined to give details, citing the need for discretion in its efforts to ensure the hostage's safe return. Its only advice to the public and media at this juncture is to respect the privacy of the individuals family and refrain from speculative reporting.

"There is absolutely no justification for any group or individual to use kidnap and the threat of violence on innocent people. We are doing all we can, in close cooperation with our international partners, to secure their safe and swift release," said the Foreign Office in a statement.

In the UK, vigils have been held across different parts of the country in solidarity with the imprisoned aid worker, amplifying the plea for his immediate release.

In a thrilling encounter, Scotland will face Italy this Saturday in a match that promises to be a highlight of the rugby calendar. The game, which will take place at Murrayfield Stadium, is expected to draw a large crowd, with fans eager to see how both teams will perform.

Scotland, who have been showing a strong performance in recent matches, are looking to continue their winning streak. Head coach Gregor Townsend has expressed confidence in his team, stating that they are prepared and ready to face the Italian side. 

"We've been working hard in training and the players are eager to get out there and show what they can do," said Townsend. "Italy are a strong team and we're not underestimating them, but we're ready for the challenge."

On the other hand, Italy, despite a few setbacks in their previous games, are determined to make a strong comeback. Italian coach Franco Smith has made several changes to his starting line-up in an attempt to inject some fresh energy into the team.

"We know we have a tough game ahead of us, but we're focused and ready," said Smith. "We've made some changes and I believe these players have what it takes to deliver a strong performance."

The match is expected to be a tough one, with both teams boasting a mix of experienced players and promising new talent. Scotland's Finn Russell and Stuart Hogg are expected to be key players, while Italy will be looking to the likes of Paolo Garbisi and Michele Lamaro to make an impact.

The game will also be a significant one for Scotland's captain, Stuart Hogg, who will earn his 80th cap. Hogg, who has been in excellent form recently, will undoubtedly be a player to watch.

As the anticipation builds, fans from both sides are gearing up for what promises to be an exciting match. With both teams eager to claim victory, Saturday's game is set to be a thrilling encounter that rugby fans won't want to miss. 

The match will kick off at 2.15pm local time and will be broadcast live on BBC One.

Brazils unemployment has hit a record low, sparking optimism about the robustness of the nation's expanding labour market. The jobless rate has plunged to 11.8%, down from 12.4% a month earlier, marking the lowest figure recorded by the Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics (IBGE) since the study began in 2012.

Brazil, known as one of the biggest economies in Latin America, has been dealing with economic difficulties in recent years. However, with the new jobless rate, economists are predicting a turnaround. They note that the fall was driven by increases in both formal and informal employment - a positive sign of economic growth and stability.

Newly released data show about 12.5 million people were unemployed in June, down from 13.1 million in May. Moreover, Brazil's workforce has continued to rise, now reaching roughly 105.9 million people. 

However, this set of data does not necessarily reflect an entirely rosy picture. While the fall in the unemployment rate is a welcome development, the increase in informal jobsreferring to roles that lack employment contracts or social benefits, usually with lower wagesis also a matter of concern. Approximately 40% of Brazilians work in such conditions.

Economists have also pointed out that the drop in unemployment is partly due to seasonal influences. A temporary increase in jobs, particularly in the service and retail sectors, is common in the second half of the year.

"We are witnessing an economy on the recovery path from the severe recession between 2015-2016", says Ricardo Amorim, a renowned Brazilian economist. "However, it is crucial that structural reforms continue so that these numbers do not prove to be ephemeral and make irrefutable the improvement in the living standards of Brazilians."

While job creation is clearly moving in a positive direction, the country's economic policymakers must strive to ensure stable economic growth to truly slash unemployment rates and provide decent, contracted work for the populace.

The government, under President Jair Bolsonaro, has pledged to accelerate economic growth through deregulation, tax reduction, and the execution of a wide-ranging pension reform. However, these actions still have to translate into tangible benefits for the labour market.

With Brazil's economy still on shaky ground, this dip in unemployment comes as a sliver of positive news. Whether this promising trend will continue, remains to be seen.

Russian state-owned company Rosneft has acquired a unit of the now-defunct oil giant Yukos for $9bn at an auction. The sale is part of the Russian government's ongoing effort to dismantle Yukos and sell off its assets.

The unit, Yuganskneftegas, was Yukos' main oil-producing subsidiary, accounting for about 60% of the company's oil output. It was put up for auction to help pay off Yukos' massive tax debts, which the Russian authorities claim amount to $27.5bn.

Rosneft, which is majority-owned by the Russian government, was the only bidder in the auction. The starting price for the unit was set at $8.65bn, and Rosneft's winning bid was only slightly higher, at $9.35bn.

The sale of Yuganskneftegas is the latest development in the long-running saga of Yukos, once Russia's largest oil company. Its former CEO, Mikhail Khodorkovsky, was arrested in 2003 on charges of tax evasion and fraud, which he claims were politically motivated.

The Russian government began dismantling Yukos in 2004, seizing its assets and selling them off to state-owned companies. This has been widely seen as part of President Vladimir Putin's strategy to increase state control over Russia's oil and gas industry.

The auction of Yuganskneftegas has been controversial, with critics arguing that the sale was rigged in favour of Rosneft. Yukos' management has also claimed that the auction was illegal and has vowed to challenge it in court.

However, the Russian authorities have defended the auction, saying it was necessary to recover the huge tax debts owed by Yukos. They have also dismissed claims that the sale was politically motivated, arguing that it was simply a matter of enforcing the law.

The acquisition of Yuganskneftegas will significantly boost Rosneft's oil production capacity, making it one of the largest oil companies in Russia. It will also further consolidate the Russian government's control over the country's oil industry.

In an era where technology is advancing at an unprecedented pace, the future seems to be fitting comfortably in our pockets. Smartphones, once a luxury, have now become a necessity, evolving into a hub of futuristic technology that is transforming our lives in ways we could never have imagined.

The smartphone industry is continuously innovating, with tech giants like Apple, Samsung, and Google pushing the boundaries of what these pocket-sized devices can do. From augmented reality to artificial intelligence, the future of technology is not in some far-off sci-fi world; it's right here in our hands.

Augmented Reality (AR) is one of the most exciting advancements in smartphone technology. AR overlays digital information onto the real world, providing users with an immersive experience that seamlessly blends reality with the digital world. Apps like Pokemon Go and Snapchat have popularised AR, but its potential extends far beyond gaming and social media. For instance, IKEA's AR app allows customers to virtually place furniture in their homes before making a purchase, revolutionising the shopping experience.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) is another groundbreaking technology that is becoming increasingly integrated into our smartphones. AI assistants like Siri, Alexa, and Google Assistant are becoming more sophisticated, capable of understanding and responding to complex commands. AI is also powering advancements in image and speech recognition, predictive text, and personalised recommendations, making our smartphones smarter and more intuitive.

5G technology is set to take the smartphone experience to the next level. With speeds up to 100 times faster than 4G, 5G will enable smoother video streaming, more efficient remote work, and even the potential for real-time augmented reality experiences. As 5G networks continue to roll out worldwide, the future of smartphone technology looks incredibly promising.

Biometric technology is another area where smartphones are leading the way. Fingerprint scanners and facial recognition systems are now commonplace, providing a secure and convenient way to unlock devices and authenticate transactions. Looking ahead, we could see even more advanced biometric technologies, such as iris scanning or vein pattern recognition.

The future of technology is not just about what our devices can do, but also how they can improve our lives. Health and wellness apps are becoming increasingly popular, with features like sleep tracking, meditation guides, and fitness coaching. In addition, smartphones are playing a crucial role in telemedicine, allowing patients to consult with healthcare professionals without leaving their homes.

In conclusion, the future is not just in our pockets; it's also being shaped by our pockets. As smartphones continue to evolve, they will undoubtedly play an even more significant

Former world number one, Marat Safin, suffered a surprising defeat at the Dubai Tennis Championships, adding another setback to his already struggling season. The Russian tennis star was ousted in the first round by an unseeded player, marking a disappointing start to his campaign in the Middle East.

Safin, who was once considered one of the most formidable players on the circuit, has been struggling to regain his form after a series of injuries and inconsistent performances. His loss in Dubai is a stark reminder of the challenges he faces in his quest to return to the top of the game.

The two-time Grand Slam winner was visibly frustrated throughout the match, struggling to find his rhythm against his lower-ranked opponent. Despite showing flashes of his former brilliance, Safin was unable to maintain his momentum, eventually succumbing to a straight-sets defeat.

The shock loss is a significant blow to Safin's confidence, who had hoped to use the Dubai Championships as a springboard to kickstart his season. Instead, the Russian will have to go back to the drawing board, reassess his game plan and work on his fitness to ensure he is ready for the upcoming tournaments.

Safin's early exit from the tournament is also a disappointment for the event organisers, who had hoped that the former world number one's participation would draw in large crowds. However, the tournament still boasts a strong field, including several top-ranked players who will be vying for the title.

Despite his recent struggles, Safin remains a popular figure in the tennis world, known for his fiery temperament and powerful game. Fans will be hoping that the Russian can bounce back from this setback and recapture some of his former glory in the coming months.

The Dubai Tennis Championships continues this week, with the remaining players battling it out for the prestigious title. As for Safin, his focus will now shift to the next tournament, where he will be hoping to put this shock loss behind him and return to winning ways.

Rap superstar Eminem has surpassed the King of Rock and Roll, Elvis Presley, to claim the number one spot on the charts. This achievement makes Eminem the solo artist with the most number one albums in the UK.

Eminem's latest album, "Music to be Murdered By - Side B," has topped the Official Charts Company's rankings, marking his 10th consecutive chart-topping album in the UK. This feat surpasses Elvis Presley's record of nine number one albums.

The Detroit rapper's surprise release, a companion to January's "Music to be Murdered By," features collaborations with artists such as Dr. Dre, Ty Dolla $ign, and Skylar Grey. The album has been well-received by fans and critics alike, further cementing Eminem's status as one of the most successful and influential artists in the music industry.

Eminem, whose real name is Marshall Mathers, first topped the UK charts in 2000 with "The Marshall Mathers LP." Since then, he has consistently released chart-topping albums, demonstrating his enduring appeal and relevance in the ever-evolving music landscape.

Despite the controversy often surrounding his lyrics, Eminem's success is undeniable. His albums have sold millions of copies worldwide, and he has won numerous awards, including 15 Grammy Awards.

Elvis Presley, known as the "King of Rock and Roll," held the record for the most number one albums by a solo artist in the UK for nearly 40 years. His posthumous album, "The Wonder of You," reached number one in 2016.

Eminem's achievement is a testament to his longevity and influence in the music industry. Despite the changing trends and tastes in music, the rapper's ability to connect with audiences through his raw and often controversial lyrics has kept him at the top of the charts for over two decades.

The Official Charts Company's chief executive, Martin Talbot, said, "Eminem continues to push boundaries, and his latest number one album makes him one of the greatest artists in the history of the Official Albums Chart."

As Eminem surpasses Elvis Presley's record, he further cements his place in music history. His achievement is a testament to his talent, hard work, and the enduring appeal of his music.

Iran's government has proposed a budget that aims to raise billions of dollars through the privatisation of state-owned assets. The move is seen as a response to crippling sanctions and the economic fallout from the Covid-19 pandemic.

The budget proposal, presented to parliament by President Ebrahim Raisi, seeks to generate around $3.4bn through the sale of state-owned companies and properties. The plan is part of a broader strategy to reduce the country's dependence on oil revenues and to cope with the economic challenges posed by US sanctions and the global pandemic.

The proposed budget for the next Iranian year, starting on 21 March, is around 17,630 trillion rials ($67bn at the free market exchange rate), a 40% increase compared to the current year's budget. However, the budget is based on an oil price of $65 a barrel, which is significantly higher than the current price.

The privatisation plan includes the sale of shares in some of the country's largest companies, including those in the oil, gas, petrochemical, mining, and telecommunications sectors. The government also plans to sell properties and other assets.

The move has been met with criticism from some quarters, with opponents arguing that it could lead to job losses and increased inequality. However, the government insists that the privatisation will lead to greater efficiency and competitiveness in the economy.

The budget proposal also includes measures to increase tax revenues and reduce government expenditure. It aims to cut public sector salaries and pensions, while increasing taxes on goods and services.

The budget still needs to be approved by parliament and the Guardian Council, a body that vets all legislation. It is expected to face opposition from some lawmakers who are concerned about the impact of the privatisation on the economy and on the livelihoods of ordinary Iranians.

The proposed budget comes at a time when Iran's economy is under severe strain. The country has been hit hard by US sanctions, which were reimposed in 2018 after the US withdrew from the Iran nuclear deal. The sanctions have cut off Iran's access to international financial markets and have led to a sharp fall in oil exports, the country's main source of revenue.

The Covid-19 pandemic has further exacerbated the economic crisis, with a sharp drop in oil demand and a slowdown in economic activity. The government has struggled to provide adequate support to businesses and households affected by the pandemic, leading to widespread discontent and protests.

The Liberal Democrats have unveiled plans to support first-time home buyers in their manifesto for the upcoming general elections in the UK. The proposals would seek to make it easier for young individuals and families to purchase their first home.

The Lib Dems' plan for first-time buyers includes the introduction of 'Rent to Own' homes. Under this scheme, new homes would be made available to first-time buyers to rent at market rates, with the option to purchase a part of the property each year. After 30 years, those in the scheme would become full owners of the property.

Furthermore, the partys proposal highlights a 'Help to Rent' scheme designed to support young people saving for a deposit. This would involve government-backed tenancy deposit loans for all first-time renters under 30, providing affordability and convenience to those struggling to accumulate enough funds for a deposit.

Jo Swinson, leader of the Lib Dems, speaks passionately about the proposal. "Our revolutionary Rent to Own scheme would greatly help younger people who have not been able to get a foot on the housing ladder," she stated. "We will ensure they have the chance to buy their own homes while renting."

Critics, however, have questioned the feasibility of the rent-to-own scheme, stating that it could lead to increased house prices and unaffordability. Some also fear it might put added pressure on the already strained housing market.

However, Ms. Swinson is confident that the partys plans will work well. "The policy will create a whole new generation of home-owners, empowering young people to take charge of their future and own their own homes," she stated.

In addition to the 'Rent to Own' and 'Help to Rent' plans, the Lib Dems also aim to build 300,000 properties per year by 2024, including 100,000 units of social housing. The party also advocates for renting rights such as longer-term tenancies, banning letting fees for tenants, and capping upfront deposits.
