The proposals serve as a part of the broader Lib Dem strategy to alleviate the housing crisis in the UK and provide homes for all. However, the success of these bold policies will depend on the partys performance in the imminent general elections.

European Union (EU) ministers are set to consider a proposal to impose a tax on jet fuel in an effort to reduce carbon emissions from aviation, a sector that currently accounts for about 2.5% of global carbon dioxide emissions.

The proposal, which will be discussed at a meeting of EU finance ministers, is part of a broader effort to meet the bloc's ambitious climate goals, which include reducing greenhouse gas emissions by at least 55% by 2030 compared to 1990 levels.

Currently, jet fuel for international flights is exempt from taxes under an international agreement dating back to the 1940s. However, the EU has the power to tax fuel for flights within the bloc, a move that could significantly increase the cost of air travel.

The proposal has been met with resistance from the aviation industry, which argues that a tax on jet fuel would increase costs for airlines and passengers, potentially damaging the sector's recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic.

However, environmental groups have welcomed the proposal, arguing that the aviation sector needs to do more to reduce its carbon emissions. They argue that a tax on jet fuel would encourage airlines to invest in cleaner technologies and more fuel-efficient aircraft.

The proposal is likely to face a tough battle to win approval from all 27 EU member states, some of which have significant aviation industries. Any decision to impose a tax on jet fuel would need to be agreed unanimously by all EU countries.

The EU has been stepping up its efforts to combat climate change in recent years, with measures including a carbon pricing system for industries and plans to phase out the sale of new petrol and diesel cars by 2035.

The proposal to tax jet fuel comes as the bloc is also considering a separate plan to include the aviation sector in its carbon pricing system, which would force airlines to buy permits for the carbon dioxide they emit.

The discussions on a jet fuel tax are part of a wider debate in the EU about how to finance the bloc's transition to a low-carbon economy. Other proposals under consideration include a levy on digital services and a tax on financial transactions.

The official website of former US President George W. Bush has been temporarily blocked following a cyber attack. The incident has raised concerns about the security of information related to the former president and his administration.

The website, which contains archives of speeches, press releases, and other official documents from Bush's presidency, was targeted by unidentified hackers. The nature of the attack and the extent of the damage are currently under investigation.

A spokesperson for the former president confirmed the incident, stating, "We are aware of the issue and are working to resolve it. We have taken the necessary steps to protect the site and its contents."

The attack comes at a time when cyber security has become a major concern for governments and corporations worldwide. It also highlights the potential vulnerability of websites associated with high-profile individuals and institutions.

While the motive behind the attack remains unclear, experts suggest it could range from a simple act of vandalism to a more sophisticated attempt to access sensitive information. 

The Bush website is not the first to be targeted. In recent years, several websites associated with US politicians have been attacked. This includes the campaign websites of both 2020 presidential candidates, which faced numerous cyber threats.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) and the Department of Homeland Security's Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) have been alerted about the incident. Both agencies have been actively involved in efforts to improve the nation's cyber defenses.

The attack on the Bush website underscores the need for robust cyber security measures, not just for government institutions, but also for individuals and organizations in the public eye.

As the investigation continues, the website remains offline to ensure the integrity of its contents and the security of its systems. It is unclear when the site will be restored, but officials assure that every effort is being made to bring it back online as soon as possible.

The former president's office has urged the public to be patient and understanding, emphasizing that the safety and security of the website's information is their top priority.

Former UK Prime Minister Tony Blair has dismissed calls to heed advice regarding the situation in Iraq, stating that he stands by his decisions made during his time in office. This comes amid growing criticism of his handling of the Iraq War and its aftermath.

Mr Blair, who led the UK into the Iraq War in 2003, has been under increasing pressure to respond to claims that he ignored expert advice on the potential consequences of the conflict. Critics argue that his decisions have contributed to the current instability in the Middle East.

However, in a defiant interview, Mr Blair stated, "I made the decisions I thought were right at the time, based on the information I had. I stand by those decisions." He further added that he believes it is "unfair" to link the current situation in Iraq to decisions made over a decade ago.

The former Prime Minister also rejected the notion that he should have listened more to military and diplomatic experts. "I listened to a wide range of advice and ultimately, as Prime Minister, I had to make the final decision. I accept responsibility for those decisions, but I will not accept the premise that they were wrong," he said.

Mr Blair's comments have sparked a fresh wave of controversy, with critics accusing him of refusing to acknowledge any mistakes in his handling of the Iraq War. Some have called for a new inquiry into the war and its aftermath, arguing that lessons must be learned to prevent similar situations in the future.

However, supporters of Mr Blair argue that he acted in what he believed were the best interests of the UK and the wider world, and that the situation in Iraq would have been far worse under Saddam Hussein's regime.

The debate over the Iraq War and its legacy continues to divide opinion, both in the UK and internationally. As the situation in Iraq remains unstable, the decisions made by Mr Blair and his government continue to be scrutinised and debated.

Danish winger Jesper Gronkjaer has agreed to a transfer to Spanish giants Real Madrid, ending his stint with English club Chelsea. The move is expected to bolster Madrid's attacking options as they aim to reclaim the La Liga title.

Gronkjaer, 28, has been a key player for Chelsea since joining the club in 2000. His pace and crossing ability have made him a constant threat on the wings, contributing significantly to Chelsea's success in recent seasons. However, the opportunity to play for one of the world's most prestigious clubs proved too enticing for the Danish international.

Real Madrid have been keen to strengthen their squad following a disappointing season, which saw them finish fourth in La Liga. The acquisition of Gronkjaer is seen as a significant step towards achieving this goal. His experience and skill set are expected to complement the team's existing attacking talents, including Brazilian superstar Ronaldo and French maestro Zinedine Zidane.

Real Madrid's sporting director, Jorge Valdano, expressed his delight at securing Gronkjaer's services. "Jesper is a world-class player who will add a new dimension to our attack," he said. "His speed, skill and experience will be invaluable as we aim to challenge for the title next season."

Gronkjaer's move to Madrid is subject to a medical, which is expected to take place later this week. If all goes well, he will join his new teammates for pre-season training in July.

The transfer fee has not been disclosed, but it is believed to be in the region of 15 million. This would make Gronkjaer one of the most expensive Danish players in history, surpassing the 13 million Liverpool paid for Daniel Agger in 2006.

Gronkjaer's departure will be a blow for Chelsea, who will now need to find a replacement for their influential winger. However, with a wealth of talent at their disposal and a substantial transfer budget, the Blues are expected to move quickly to fill the void left by the Dane's departure.

Ringtones sellers are to face stringent new regulations in an effort to clamp down on unscrupulous practices and protect consumers, under new rules announced by the UK telecoms regulator. The move follows a significant rise in complaints from mobile phone users about excessive costs and hidden charges.

The Ofcom regulator has said that the new rules will strongly regulate the ringtone industry, which had previously operated with relative freedom. This follows an alarming increase in the number of complaints arising from misleading advertisements, unclear subscription terms and inflated costs. 

In many cases, users reported being lured into expensive monthly subscriptions for ringtones without their explicit agreement or understanding of the terms. Several phone users also claimed to have been billed for ringtones and other mobile services that were never used or delivered.

To tackle this, Ofcom is set to introduce a number of stringent rules aimed at making sure consumers are not hoodwinked by unscrupulous companies or complex terms and conditions. The regulators new guidelines stipulate that pricing information for any ringtone service must be clearly provided to the user at the point of purchase. In addition, firms will need to take steps to ensure that customers are fully aware they have entered into a recurring payment situation.

Under the new rules, advertising and marketing communications from these companies must also be honest and transparent. They should not mislead the consumers or omit important information about the cost of the service or the duration of the contract. 

A new rule that may give further relief to the customers is the 'cooling-off' period. Companies will now be required to offer a minimum 14-day 'cooling-off' period during which customers can cancel their purchase without being charged. 

In a statement, Ofcom said that the protection of consumers is a priority. We will fully investigate complaints and take robust action where necessary," a spokesperson added. The regulations will come into effect two months from now.

This move by Ofcom is viewed as a welcome step towards greater transparency in how digital services are offered and sold, putting an end to misleading practices that have left many consumers out of pocket over the years in the UK. 

While this new regulation is shaking up the ringtone industry, it is expected that other mobile and tech-related sectors might also come under similar scrutiny in near future. This could result in wider transparency and better protection for mobile users in the UK.

Unilever, the multinational consumer goods giant, is set to undergo a significant shake-up as it grapples with a slip in profits. The company, which owns brands such as Dove, Ben & Jerry's, and Lipton, has seen a decline in its financial performance, prompting a strategic review of its operations.

The company's latest financial report revealed a 5% drop in underlying operating profit to 9.4bn (8.1bn) for the year 2021. This comes despite a 3.5% increase in turnover to 51bn (43.8bn). The company attributed the profit slip to increased costs of raw materials and logistics, exacerbated by the global supply chain disruptions.

In response to the disappointing results, Unilever's CEO, Alan Jope, announced a series of measures aimed at improving the company's financial performance. These include a comprehensive review of its business portfolio, cost-cutting initiatives, and a renewed focus on high-growth segments.

"We are not satisfied with our performance and are determined to improve our competitiveness and profitability," Jope said in a statement. "We are taking decisive action to simplify our business, drive efficiency, and accelerate growth in high-potential areas."

As part of the shake-up, Unilever will be reviewing its tea business, which includes brands such as PG Tips and Lipton. The company had previously announced plans to separate this division, but the process has been delayed due to the pandemic. The review will also extend to other underperforming segments of the business.

The cost-cutting measures are expected to result in job losses, although the company has not yet provided specific details. Unilever has also pledged to increase its investment in digital marketing and e-commerce, areas that have seen significant growth during the pandemic.

The announcement of the shake-up has been met with mixed reactions from investors. While some have welcomed the decisive action, others have expressed concern about the potential impact on the company's workforce and the broader implications for the consumer goods sector.

Unilever's share price fell by 2.5% in early trading following the announcement, reflecting investor uncertainty about the company's future direction.

The shake-up at Unilever comes at a time of significant challenges for the consumer goods sector, with companies grappling with rising costs, supply chain disruptions, and changing consumer habits. It remains to be seen how successful Unilever's measures will be in reversing its profit slip and positioning the company for future growth.

In a move that recognises his longstanding contribution to Hollywood, iconic actor Keanu Reeves has been awarded his own star on Hollywoods world-famous Walk of Fame.

The actor, well known for his roles in blockbusters like "The Matrix" trilogy, "John Wick," and "Speed," was all smiles on Wednesday as he knelt down to sign his name next to the shiny new star that carries his name.

Reeves, humble as always, thanked his fans, his friends, and his colleagues for their support in an emotion-filled speech. He said, "People don't know the years, the time, the dedication it takes to succeed in this business. I am truly humbled to be here."

The Canadian-born actor began his thumping Hollywood career in the 1980s, moving from successfully doing commercials and small TV roles to becoming one of Hollywood's highest-paid actors by the 2000s.

Despite facing personal and professional ups and downs, Reeves remains one of the most beloved and revered figures in Hollywood due to his unchanging humility and generosity.

Luminaries who were present to honour Reeves included his co-stars from "Cloud Atlas," Halle Berry and Ian McShane. In her speech, Berry termed Reeves as "an incredible man, on camera and off" and "the hardest-working actor I've ever met."

Rana Ghadban, the president and CEO of the Hollywood Chamber of Commerce, said in a statement, "We are very delighted to honour Keanu Reeves with his much-deserved star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame."

Ghadban also added, "Keanu is a great actor who has displayed amazing versatility and staying power in an industry that is constantly changing. His movies have brought joy to millions of viewers around the world."

Reeves continues to delight fans across the globe, with his latest outing, "The Matrix Resurrections," set to hit theaters and HBO Max later this month.

As he stepped off the podium, Keanu paused, looked at his newly-minted star, and with his signature dazzling smile, joked, "This looks like a good spot. I hope my dog doesn't pee on it."

Here's to the honouring of a true star in every sense of the word, ensuring his name will be embedded forever in Hollywoods rich and vibrant history.

Shares in music giant EMI have taken a hit following a profit warning issued by the company. The warning, which predicted lower than expected profits for the year, has led to a significant drop in the company's share price.

EMI, home to artists such as Coldplay and Katy Perry, saw its shares fall by 16% in early trading, wiping off nearly 200m from its market value. The company blamed the profit warning on poor sales in North America and a delay in the release of several key albums.

The music giant now expects its profits for the year to be "significantly below" previous forecasts. This is the second profit warning issued by the company in less than six months, which has raised concerns among investors about the company's financial health.

Analysts have suggested that the profit warning could make EMI more vulnerable to a takeover. The company has been the subject of takeover speculation in recent months, with several potential buyers reportedly interested.

EMI's chief executive, Eric Nicoli, said the company was "disappointed" with the profit warning but remained "confident in the strength of our music portfolio". He added that the company was taking "decisive action" to address its issues in North America.

The profit warning comes at a challenging time for the music industry, which has been grappling with declining CD sales and the rise of digital music. EMI has been trying to adapt to these changes, investing heavily in digital music and signing deals with online music platforms.

However, the company's efforts have so far failed to offset the decline in physical sales, leading to lower than expected revenues. The delay in the release of several key albums, including new records from Norah Jones and Gorillaz, has also impacted the company's earnings.

The profit warning is a blow to EMI, which has been struggling to compete with rivals such as Universal Music and Sony Music. The company will now be under pressure to reassure investors about its future prospects and to demonstrate that it can adapt to the changing music landscape.

The UK government has announced a ban on forced retirement before the age of 65, in a move hailed as a significant step towards ending age discrimination in the workplace. The new legislation, which comes into effect immediately, will make it illegal for companies to compel employees to retire before they reach 65, unless it can be objectively justified.

The decision follows a series of high-profile legal cases in which employees challenged their employers over enforced retirement. The government has said that the new law will provide greater job security for older workers and allow them to contribute to the economy for longer.

The Minister for Pensions and Ageing Society, said: "Forcing people to retire before they are ready is not only unfair, but it also deprives the economy of valuable skills and experience. This new law will ensure that people have the choice to continue working and contributing to the economy."

The move has been welcomed by age equality campaigners, who argue that the previous rules were discriminatory and out of touch with modern working practices. The charity Age UK described the ban as a "major victory" for older workers.

However, some business groups have expressed concerns about the change. They argue that it could lead to increased costs for companies, particularly small businesses, and make workforce planning more difficult.

The Confederation of British Industry (CBI) said it recognised the benefits of a diverse workforce but warned that the ban could have unintended consequences. "Businesses need to have the flexibility to manage their workforce and this includes being able to plan for the future," a spokesperson said.

Under the new law, employers will still be able to include a retirement age in contracts, but they will have to be able to objectively justify it. This could include jobs that require certain physical abilities or high levels of mental agility.

The ban on forced retirement under 65 is part of a wider government strategy to respond to the changing demographics of the UK workforce. With people living and staying healthy for longer, and with a rising state pension age, the government believes it is essential to remove barriers to older people working.

The government has also pledged to review the new law in five years' time to ensure it is working effectively and to make any necessary adjustments.

In a world where digital technology is rapidly evolving, recently, mobile phones have become an almost indispensable part of our daily lives. Consequently, with companies like Apple and Samsung releasing new models every year, the number of outdated, unused phones cluttering our homes is on the rise. This not only contributes to pollution but also results in valuable resources being wasted. But what if these old phones could be given a new life?

Companies across the globe are now finding innovative ways to repurpose these old mobile phones, ensuring that they do not end up in landfills. From transforming them into educational tools to using them as components in new products, the business of "upcycling" old phones is steadily growing, providing a solution to the mounting issue of electronic waste.

In the UK alone, it is estimated that there are about 40 million unused phones gathering dust in drawers. They contain precious elements such as gold, silver, copper, platinum and palladium, which can be extracted and reused, making a significant impact on reducing mining and its associated environmental damage.

A London-based start-up, Giffgaff, is playing a pivotal role in the phone recycle scheme. The company's recent initiative encourages people to send in their old phones in exchange for payment, and then refurbishes and resells them, providing affordable phones to buyers and minimising waste.

Elsewhere, in a bid to combat e-waste in Africa, companies like Close The Gap offer digital training using old phones to young, unemployed people, primarily in East Africa. Similarly, Rainforest Connection has turned used phones into forest guardians. Equipped with solar charging capacity, these devices listen for illegal logging activity in vulnerable forests, helping in the fight against deforestation. 

Not only does the recycling or upcycling of phones protect the environment, but it also fosters social benefits. Some organisations, for instance, donate refurbished devices to the underprivileged, giving them access to vital digital services.

In an effort to promote such initiatives, various campaigns are raising awareness about the benefits of upcycling old devices. One such campaign is the Royal Society of Chemistry's "New life for old phones" initiative, which aims to educate the public about the valuable resources within their gadgets and the importance of recycling them.

While we're still some way from mainstream phone recycling, these innovative initiatives show promise, presenting a world where upgrading your phone does not contribute to mounting landfills, rather leads to the education of an unemployed youth in Africa, the detection of illegal logging in rainforests, or the connection of a low

Grammy-winning singer Alicia Keys is set to open the US Super Bowl, one of the most-watched television events in the United States. The National Football League (NFL) confirmed the news, adding that Keys will perform the national anthem before the start of the game.

The Super Bowl, which is the championship game of the NFL, is scheduled to take place on February 13, 2023. The event is known for its high-profile halftime shows and pre-game performances, which often feature some of the biggest names in music.

Alicia Keys, a 15-time Grammy winner, is no stranger to the Super Bowl stage. She previously performed the national anthem at the Super Bowl in 2013, delivering a powerful rendition on the piano. This year, she will once again grace the stage, promising a performance that will set the tone for the rest of the event.

"We are thrilled to have Alicia Keys open the Super Bowl with her incredible talent," said Brian Rolapp, Chief Media and Business Officer for the NFL. "Her previous performance was unforgettable, and we have no doubt that she will once again deliver a rendition of the national anthem that will resonate with viewers across the country."

Keys, known for hits like "Fallin'" and "No One," has sold over 65 million records worldwide. She has also been a prominent voice in various social issues, using her platform to advocate for racial equality and women's rights.

The singer expressed her excitement about the upcoming performance on social media, stating, "I'm honored to be a part of such an iconic event. Can't wait to share this moment with you all."

The Super Bowl halftime show, which has previously featured performances from artists like Jennifer Lopez, Shakira, and The Weeknd, is yet to announce its headliner. However, with Alicia Keys opening the event, viewers can expect a spectacular start to the game.

The Super Bowl will be broadcast live on CBS and other partner networks. It is expected to draw millions of viewers, making it one of the most-watched television events of the year.

The UK's manufacturing sector is facing a significant threat, with thousands of jobs at risk, prompting urgent calls for government intervention to save the industry. 

The manufacturing industry, which contributes 192 billion to the economy and employs 2.7 million people, has been hit hard by the ongoing pandemic and the aftermath of Brexit. The sector has seen a sharp decline in output, with many companies struggling to stay afloat. 

Trade unions and industry leaders are now urging the government to step in and provide much-needed support to prevent further job losses. They are calling for a comprehensive recovery plan that includes financial aid, tax incentives, and measures to boost domestic demand for UK-made products. 

"Without immediate action, we risk losing a significant portion of our manufacturing base and the high-skilled jobs it provides," warned Stephen Phipson, CEO of Make UK, the manufacturers' organisation. "This is not just about protecting the present, but also safeguarding the future of manufacturing in the UK."

The call comes as new data reveals that the manufacturing sector contracted by 10% in 2020, the largest fall in output since the financial crisis of 2008. The automotive and aerospace industries have been particularly affected, with thousands of jobs already lost.

Unite, the country's largest trade union, has also voiced its concern. "The government must act now to save our manufacturing jobs and invest in the future of this vital sector," said Unite's assistant general secretary for manufacturing, Steve Turner. "We need a clear, long-term industrial strategy that supports our manufacturers and promotes growth."

The government has responded to the calls, stating that it recognises the importance of the manufacturing sector and is committed to supporting it. A spokesperson for the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy said: "We are working closely with the industry to understand the challenges it faces and will continue to provide support through our various business support schemes."

However, critics argue that the current support measures are not enough and that more targeted assistance is needed to save jobs and stimulate growth in the sector. They are calling for a more proactive approach, including direct investment in key industries, increased support for research and development, and measures to promote skills training and apprenticeships.

The manufacturing sector is a crucial part of the UK economy, not only in terms of output and employment but also in driving innovation and regional development. The loss of manufacturing jobs would have far-reaching implications, affecting local communities and supply chains across the country. 

As the UK navigates its post-Brexit future and continues

Organised crime-themed video games have taken over the gaming charts, with titles such as "Grand Theft Auto V" and "Mafia: Definitive Edition" leading the pack. This surge in popularity suggests a growing fascination among gamers for narratives that revolve around the underworld.

"Grand Theft Auto V", developed by Rockstar Games, has consistently topped the charts since its release in 2013. The game, set in the fictional city of Los Santos, allows players to engage in a variety of criminal activities, from car theft to bank robberies. Its immersive storyline and open-world gameplay have made it a favourite among gamers worldwide.

Meanwhile, "Mafia: Definitive Edition", a remake of the 2002 classic, has also seen a significant rise in sales. The game, developed by Hangar 13 and published by 2K, takes players back to the Prohibition era, where they navigate the criminal underworld of the fictional city of Lost Heaven.

The success of these games is not just down to their engaging gameplay and high-quality graphics. The allure also lies in the narratives they offer, which often involve complex characters and moral dilemmas. These games provide players with an opportunity to explore a darker side of life, albeit in a virtual setting.

However, the dominance of gangster-themed games in the charts has also sparked concerns among some critics. They argue that these games may glorify violence and criminal behaviour, potentially influencing impressionable young players. 

In response, game developers and industry experts have highlighted the age ratings and parental controls available in these games. They also point out that video games, like movies and books, are a form of entertainment and storytelling, and should not be held solely responsible for influencing behaviour.

Despite the controversy, the popularity of gangster-themed games shows no signs of waning. As technology continues to advance, gamers can expect even more immersive and complex narratives from the underworld in the future.

In an effort to diversify its economic profile and reduce its reliance on oil, the Nigerian government has announced plans to significantly increase cocoa production over the next few years. This decision was made considering the recent unpredictable nature of the global oil markets and the detrimental impact it has had on Nigeria's economy.

Nigeria, the world's fourth-largest cocoa producer, exports nearly a quarter of its annual production, with imports primarily going to Europe. The government's plan to boost production will likely increase the nations export capabilities, while giving it a stronger foothold in the global cocoa market.

The government's strategy includes the modernisation of farming methods, improved access to agricultural financing, and the promotion of sustainable and environmentally friendly farming practices amongst local farmers. This also includes the possibility of providing farmers with improved cocoa seedlings and training them on pruning and fermentation processes which could double yield.

By embracing new agricultural techniques and prioritizing cocoa crop, we hope to increase production from our current 250,000 tonnes output to 500,000 tonnes by 2024, said Nigeria's Minister of Agriculture and Rural Development, Sabo Nanono. 

This initiative is also likely to bring significant socio-economic benefits. Besides generating more revenue, increased cocoa production will create jobs, encouraging the younger generation to consider agriculture as an attractive field to work in. 

Mr. Nanono emphasized the necessity for agricultural diversification, saying, "Although oil and gas continue to dominate Nigeria's economic landscape, we have started to appreciate the value of 'green gold' that can additionally bolster our recovery and growth. The expansion of our cocoa industry can help to create a more diverse and sustainable economy."

However, the plan faces several challenges. Ageing trees, lack of modern farming equipment, the absence of a futures market, and unpredictable weather patterns could hamper the efforts to increase cocoa production. The government has, in response, pledged to address these issues gradually, to ensure that their goal to provide a substantial cocoa yield becomes viable.

Renewed emphasis on increasing cocoa production showcases Nigeria's intention to reduce dependency on oil and its determination to build a more diversified and resilient economy. It is a nod to both domestic economic demands and wider global sustainability trends, recognizing the need for economic activities that are both profitable and beneficial to farmers, the wider population, and the environment.

Embattled Sports Minister, John Pearson, remains unyieldly amidst hefty criticism over the ongoing doping scandal that has tainted the reputation of British athletics.

Pearson faced robust questioning today in Parliament over allegations that the government mishandled intelligence on systemic performance-enhancing drug use in athletics.

Members from across the political spectrum joined in the questioning, as it emerged the Sport Ministry had received a classified report outlining alleged doping activities a month before the scandal broke out in the public domain. The document was from the UK Anti-Doping Agency (UKAD), detailing suspected widespread use of banned substances within the athletic community.

Many are criticizing the minister for the delayed response to the report, arguing that a swift and transparent approach would not only have served justice sooner but also could have protected the integrity of British sport from such a scandal. 

However, Pearson said in his defence, "We have followed the appropriate protocols. As soon as we received the report, we asked UKAD for advice on the best way to address the problem, respecting the agency's independence and expertise. We were cautious about interfering with their investigations or compromising any potential legal processes.

The row has grown since Britain's Olympians returned home last month. They brought back fewer medals than expected, raising questions about whether doping had tarnished their performances. The scandal has reached a fever pitch, following high-profile suspensions of two top athletes for failing drug tests.

Pearson is under more pressure due to the pending investigation into the source of leaked documents that revealed the scale of doping. There is speculation in political corridors that the leak came from within his ministry, although he has strongly denied these claims, insisting it was unauthorised and a breach of confidentiality.

Despite these increasingly complex hurdles, Pearson remains resolute, adamant he will not step aside until the investigation is complete. He stated categorically, "I will not resign. I respect the seriousness of the issue and I am committed to seeing this through."

As the minister digs in his heels over the doping row, the future of UK Athletics hangs in the balance. Only the passage of time and a rigorous investigation will reveal the extent of the doping scandal and its impact on Britain's tarnished reputation in world athletics.

Former world champion marathon runner, Paula Radcliffe, is calling for a toughened stance against drug cheats in athletics. The retired British athlete, who set the record for fastest marathon for a female athlete back in 2003, has spoken out against leniency for doping in the sport.

Radcliffe, renowned worldwide for her durability and fortitude, believes that the current system is too soft on athletes who are found guilty of substance abuse. She is advocating for stricter punitive measures to deter potential drug cheats from damaging the integrity of athletics.

The 47-year-old stated her belief that convicted users of performance-enhancing drugs should be given lifetime bans from competing. She pointed out that as long as there is only a small risk of punishment, some athletes will continue to be swayed by the allure of artificially enhanced performance.

Radcliffes call comes amid mounting concern that the anti-doping regimen in athletics is failing to act as a robust deterrent. Several high-profile cases of doping have emerged in recent years, placing significant strain on the credibility and reputation of the sport.

The international governing body for athletics, World Athletics, currently imposes a four-year ban for athletes found guilty of doping for the first time. The second offence yields an additional eight-year suspension, effectively ending the career of the athlete.

However, Radcliffe argues that this is insufficient. "The punishment for drug cheats needs to be severe to the point where it's no longer a risk that's worth taking," she said. "The threat of ruining their career might be the only thing that truly deters some individuals."

Aside from championing for a tougher stance on doping, Radcliffe is also asking for more reliable testing systems for substances that can enhance performance, better education for athletes, and a more consistent approach to dealing with those found guilty of doping. The marathon record-holder believes that these improvements are essential to restoring faith in athletics.

"We all want a level playing field," she commented. "So every athlete has a fair shot at success. To allow that, we need significant changes to our current system."

Radcliffe's calls for reform are echoed throughout the athletics community, with widespread agreement that the existing mechanisms for preventing doping are inadequate. It is hoped her impactful words will spark further dialogue, leading to more stringent policies to safeguard the integrity of the sport.

Scientists have developed a 'brainwave' cap that allows users to control a computer using only their thoughts. The technology, which is still in its early stages, could revolutionise the way we interact with computers and potentially provide a lifeline for those with physical disabilities.

The cap, developed by a team of researchers at the University of California, San Diego, uses electroencephalogram (EEG) technology to monitor the electrical activity of the brain. The user simply thinks about moving a cursor on a screen, and the cap translates these thoughts into commands that the computer can understand.

The team, led by Dr. Thomas DeMarse, has been working on the project for several years. "The idea is to create a direct interface between the brain and the computer," he explained. "We're not reading minds, but we are picking up the electrical signals that the brain uses to control muscles."

The cap is fitted with 64 electrodes that pick up the brain's electrical signals. These signals are then amplified and sent to a computer, which uses machine learning algorithms to interpret the signals and translate them into commands.

In tests, users have been able to move a cursor around a screen, click on icons, and even type out words using a virtual keyboard. The technology is not yet perfect - it takes a lot of concentration and the cursor movement can be slow and jerky - but the team is optimistic about its potential.

"We're still in the early stages, but the results so far are promising," said Dr. DeMarse. "With further development, we believe this technology could be used to control prosthetic limbs, wheelchairs, or other devices."

The technology could also have applications in the gaming industry, allowing players to control video games with their thoughts. However, the team is primarily focused on its potential to help those with physical disabilities.

"We're really excited about the potential this technology has to improve the lives of people with disabilities," said Dr. DeMarse. "Imagine being able to control your computer, your phone, or even your home with just your thoughts. It could be life-changing."

The team is now working on refining the technology and conducting further tests. They hope to have a commercially available product within the next five years.

The movie-making industry behemoth, Disney, has thrown its weight behind Sony's DVD technology, providing it with a significant boost in the ongoing DVD format war. 

Walt Disney Company, known for its blockbuster movies and popular animation films, announced its support for the Blu-ray Disc, a high-definition DVD technology developed by Sony and the Blu-ray Disc Association. 

During an ongoing debate within the film industry about the future format of DVDs, Disney's decision swings the pendulum in favor of Sony. The two leading contenders for replacing the current DVD format are Blu-ray Disc led by Sony and the HD DVD backed by Toshiba. Both technologies claim superior quality, capacity, and data transfer; however, they are incompatible with each other. 

Disney's decision to back Sony's Blu-ray appears to be a strategic one. With the ability to store up to 50 gigabytes of data, nearly six times the capacity of the best HD DVD version, Blu-ray discs offer a richer viewing experience with better picture quality. 

Bob Chapek, President of Disney's Buena Vista Home Entertainment division said, "We certainly believe Blu-ray is the superior technology. It provides the most comprehensive entertainment experience. He also underlined the format's ability to add substantial content that isn't possible on a current DVD.

"We believe that the Blu-ray technology will not only maintain consumers' high level of satisfaction with DVD but will provide even greater enjoyment as a result of advancements in interactivity and high-definition picture and sound quality," Chapek added.

Disneys decision marks another significant step toward Blu-ray's broader acceptance. Earlier, Twentieth Century Fox and Lionsgate announced their support for Sonys technology. With some of Hollywood's biggest hitters backing Blu-ray, Sony's high-definition DVD format has certainly gained major momentum. 

This, however, does not conclude the format war. Other significant industry players, like Universal Pictures, are backing HD DVD, which is cheaper to produce. Universal has insisted there is still room for both formats to co-exist.

On the consumer front, the outcome of the format war is significant, as very soon, those buying a new DVD player will need to decide between a Blu-ray or HD DVD player, with the knowledge that one or the other could potentially become obsolete.
Nevertheless, Disney's decision to back Sony underpins the fact that the race between the two technologies is far from over.
Overall, the move shows how home entertainment's future will continue to be shaped by major parties seeking to protect their interests and make strategic alliances.

California has passed a law that sets penalties for the use and distribution of spyware. The state legislation allows people to sue for damages if they are affected by software that covertly monitors their online habits or personal data. 

Under the new law, individuals found guilty of employing or distributing spyware could face a fine of up to $1,000 and jail time of up to a year. Companies could also be slapped with fines of up to $5,000 for each day of violation.

Spyware has rapidly become a significant issue in recent years, with millions of computer users worldwide falling victim. The intrusive software can collect private information and track web browsing habits without users' knowledge or consent.

The passing of the anti-spyware law represents a significant move by the US state to curb this growing problem. Alex Padilla, the Secretary of State of California, said: "By recognizing spyware as a crime punishable by law, California is taking a stand against this invasive and harmful practice."

Other measures included in the legislation include stricter penalties for companies knowingly distributing spyware. Not only are they liable to pay a hefty fine, but their activities could also be deemed unfair business practices, potentially leading to further legal action.

Besides, the law also allows the court to order restitution in cases where victims have suffered losses as a result of spyware infection. Moreover, individuals who have been wronged by these deceptive practices can file lawsuits to recover damages.

The law has been welcomed by digital privacy advocates and cybersecurity firms. However, some critics argue that it may not be enough to deter spyware creators and distributors who operate beyond the confines of California or even the United States.

Spyware has been linked to numerous cybercrimes worldwide, including identity theft, fraud, and unauthorized access to sensitive data. Cybersecurity experts hope that California's move will set a precedent for other states and nations to adopt similar measures.

"Spyware undermines the very essence of privacy and trust in the digital age. We must take tougher actions to banish it." Padilla added.

This law is expected to come into effect on January 1st, 2023, and is seen as an essential step towards offering greater protection to internet users. It is hoped that the stringent penalties will act as a potent deterrent, drastically reducing the prevalence of spyware.

Hollywood's finest are preparing to swap the red carpet for a more relaxed setting as they gather for the annual Oscar Nominees Luncheon. The event, which is a key fixture in the awards season calendar, offers a chance for nominees to mingle and celebrate their achievements ahead of the prestigious Academy Awards ceremony.

The luncheon, held at the Beverly Hilton in Los Angeles, is a unique event in the Oscar season. Unlike the high-pressure, competitive atmosphere of the awards night, the luncheon is a more casual affair. It's a chance for the nominees to let their hair down, enjoy a meal, and celebrate their nominations with their peers.

This year's nominees, including the likes of Lady Gaga, Will Smith, and Benedict Cumberbatch, will be in attendance. They will be joined by a host of other stars, directors, and industry professionals, all eager to celebrate the best of cinema in the past year.

The event is also an opportunity for the nominees to participate in the traditional "class photo", where all the nominees gather together for a group shot. This photo often serves as a memento of the occasion and a testament to the collective talent of the year's nominees.

The luncheon is not just about celebration, however. It also serves as a reminder of the upcoming awards ceremony. With the Oscars just weeks away, the luncheon is often seen as a chance for nominees to make an impression and build momentum ahead of the big night.

The Academy Awards, or Oscars, are considered the highest honour in the film industry. This year's ceremony, which will be the 94th, is set to take place on March 27th. The event will be hosted by comedian Amy Schumer, actress Regina Hall, and producer Wanda Sykes.

As the Oscar nominees gear up for their luncheon, the anticipation for the awards night continues to build. With a diverse range of films and performances nominated this year, the race for the golden statuette is wide open. But for now, the focus is on enjoying the luncheon and celebrating the incredible achievements in film over the past year.

Spanish authorities have evacuated the Santiago Bernabeu stadium in Madrid following a bomb threat. The threat was received via an anonymous phone call to the local police station, prompting an immediate response.

The call was received at approximately 11:30 local time, with the caller stating that a bomb had been planted inside the stadium, home to the Real Madrid football team. The police immediately initiated an evacuation procedure, clearing out the stadium and surrounding areas.

The Bernabeu, one of the most iconic football stadiums in the world, was undergoing routine maintenance at the time of the threat. A small number of staff and construction workers were present and were swiftly evacuated. No injuries have been reported.

The Spanish police, in collaboration with the bomb disposal unit, are currently conducting a thorough search of the premises. They have cordoned off the area and are urging people to stay away until further notice.

The Mayor of Madrid, Jose Luis Martinez-Almeida, has praised the swift response of the police and emergency services. "The safety of our citizens is our utmost priority," he said in a statement. "We are working closely with the police to ensure the situation is resolved as quickly and safely as possible."

Real Madrid has also released a statement, expressing their gratitude to the authorities for their quick response. "We are cooperating fully with the police investigation and will provide any assistance necessary," the statement read.

The bomb threat comes at a time when Spain is on high alert following a series of terrorist attacks across Europe. The Spanish government has increased security measures at major public venues, including football stadiums, in response to the heightened threat level.

The Bernabeu stadium, which can hold more than 80,000 spectators, is a significant landmark in Madrid and a popular tourist destination. It is also a symbol of national pride, hosting numerous high-profile football matches, including the Champions League finals.

As of now, no group has claimed responsibility for the bomb threat. The investigation is ongoing, and further updates will be provided as more information becomes available.

Hollywood veteran Robert De Niro has once again proven his box office prowess with his latest film, completing what industry insiders are calling a "box office coup".

The 78-year-old actor, known for his roles in iconic films such as "Taxi Driver" and "The Godfather Part II", has seen his latest film top the box office charts, outperforming a host of other high-profile releases.

The film, whose title has been kept under wraps, has reportedly raked in an impressive $50 million in its opening weekend, surpassing industry expectations and cementing De Niro's status as a bankable star.

This box office success is a testament to De Niro's enduring appeal and his ability to draw audiences, despite the ongoing challenges posed by the pandemic to the film industry. It also marks a significant comeback for the actor, whose recent films have not performed as well commercially.

Industry analysts attribute the film's success to a combination of De Niro's star power, a compelling storyline, and a strong marketing campaign. The film's performance is also seen as a positive sign for the industry, which has been grappling with the impact of streaming services and changing viewer habits.

De Niro's box office coup comes at a time when many veteran actors are struggling to maintain their relevance in an industry increasingly dominated by superhero films and franchise sequels. His success serves as a reminder of the enduring appeal of well-crafted, character-driven films.

The actor, who has won two Academy Awards during his illustrious career, has not commented on the film's success. However, his performance has been widely praised, with critics hailing it as one of his best in recent years.

This box office coup is yet another feather in the cap for De Niro, who continues to defy age and industry trends with his compelling performances. It also serves as a reminder of his status as one of Hollywood's most respected and bankable stars.

Former Speaker of the House of Commons, Baroness Betty Boothroyd, has called for the House of Lords to have its own speaker. She believes that this would help to modernise the upper chamber and make it more accountable to the public.

Baroness Boothroyd, who served as Speaker of the House of Commons from 1992 to 2000, said that the Lords needed a speaker who could represent it to the outside world and defend its interests. She argued that the current arrangement, where the Lord Speaker has limited powers and the House is largely self-regulating, is outdated and lacks transparency.

"The House of Lords is a vital part of our parliamentary democracy," she said. "But it needs to evolve and adapt to meet the challenges of the 21st century. A speaker with real authority could help to drive that change."

Baroness Boothroyd's comments come amid ongoing debate about the role and size of the House of Lords, which is currently the second largest legislative assembly in the world after the National People's Congress of China. Critics argue that it is too large, too costly and lacks democratic legitimacy.

The Baroness suggested that a Lords speaker could be elected by members of the House, in the same way that the Speaker of the House of Commons is chosen. This, she said, would give the speaker a clear mandate and help to enhance the reputation of the Lords.

"The Speaker of the House of Commons is a well-known figure who is seen to stand up for the rights of MPs and the institution as a whole," she said. "The Lords needs a similar figurehead."

The idea of a Lords speaker is not new. It was proposed by the Wakeham Commission on the reform of the House of Lords in 2000, but was not implemented. However, Baroness Boothroyd's intervention could give fresh impetus to the idea.

The current Lord Speaker, Lord Fowler, has previously said that he would be open to the idea of a more powerful speaker role. However, any change would require legislation and could face opposition from some peers who value the Lords' tradition of self-regulation.

Baroness Boothroyd's call for a Lords speaker is likely to reignite the debate about the future of the House of Lords and its role in the UK's parliamentary democracy. It remains to be seen whether her proposal will gain traction among her fellow peers and the wider political establishment.

Former Olympic champion Jonathan Edwards believes that triple jumper Phillips Idowu has the potential to win gold for Great Britain at the forthcoming European Championships in Paris. 

Edwards, who remains the world record holder for the event, told BBC Sport that he has high hopes for the current British champion. He said, "Phillips is in great shape - physically and mentally. He has had a great run-up to the European Championships and I firmly believe he could bring home a gold".

Idowu, 31, has consistently been a standout performer for Britain at the world stage. This year alone, he has won silver medals at the World Athletics Indoor Championships and Commonwealth Games. He is one of Great Britain's biggest hopes for a medal at the European Championships, which run from 26 August to 1 September.

"I've watched Phillips over the years and his progression in the sport has been remarkable," continued Edwards. "He thrives in high-pressure environments and I don't see the European Championships as any different".

Edwards, who won the Olympic gold for the triple jump event in Sydney 2000, retired from the sport in 2003. Today, he remains closely involved in athletics and is too aware of the mental and physical strain that athletes like Idowu face.

Speaking on Idowu's chances in Paris, Edwards said, "Phillips has the calibre and the experience. He has previously competed against some of the best in the world and has come out on top. His mental strength and determination to succeed set him apart."

Edwards' endorsement comes as Idowu prepares to face tough competition from European opponents, including French athlete Teddy Tamgho, who secured the world indoor record last year.

However, Edwards believes that Idowu has the edge. "It will be a close contest", he said, "but it's gold or nothing for Phillips. He is in the best shape of his life and I firmly believe in his ability to top the podium."

As British track and field fans eagerly anticipate the week-long event, all eyes will be on Idowu. Britain's golden hopeful may just be their ticket to another thrilling athletics victory.

Football commentator and former professional player Graeme Souness has expressed interest in recruiting former England striker Michael Owen in the summer transfer window. Owen, a free agent since his departure from Stoke City in 2013, is yet to comment on the potential move.

This potential hiring would mark an intriguing chapter in Owen's illustrious career, which includes stints with Liverpool, Real Madrid, Newcastle United and Manchester United. Meanwhile, Souness, the former Liverpool and Rangers manager, now a respected pundit on Sky Sports, has consistently praised Owen's abilities on-air.

Speaking on Sky Sports, Souness stated, "There aren't many players like Michael out there anymore. His eye for a goal and his ability to stay fit for a substantial part of a season, despite his age, is what makes him a valuable player."

Experts are divided on how Owen, now 41, would fit into the competitive world of top-tier football after a long hiatus. However, Souness is confident in his abilities. "At this stage of his life, he's not the youngster who arrived at Liverpool with bags of potential," Souness acknowledged, "But he's still got the quality and experience we need."

The former Liverpool manager's admiration for Owen is well-documented. During their shared time at Liverpool, Souness was full of praise for the striker, whom he described as "one of the best finishers I've ever seen". Their enduring professional respect could be the driving force behind this potential move.

Details of the transfer, such as the duration of Owen's contract and the potential role he would play in Souness' side, remain unclear. As the transfer window approaches, fans will eagerly await confirmation of Owen's potential return to football.

Owen's possible recruitment by Souness could add a stunning twist to this summer's transfer window drama, reaffirming Souness' unorthodox and determined approach to team building.

The Christmas spirit has been disturbed by an unwelcome visitor this year, an internet worm named 'Santy'. This malicious software has been wreaking havoc throughout websites worldwide during the festive season. 

The Santy worm targets the PHP bulletin board system, a common format used by many websites for online discussions. Upon infestation, this worm changes websites to display the message: "This site is defaced!!! This site is defaced!!! NeverEverNoSanity WebWorm generation."

Recent reports have confirmed that approximately 40,000 websites were affected worldwide within 24 hours of the worms release. Varying from online businesses to personal blogs, these sites were left with the aforementioned disturbing message in place of their usual content. 

Experts reckon that the worm uses the Google search engine to find new sites to attack. Once the Santy worm infects a PHP bulletin board, it starts to create multiple threads. Each of them searches for more bulletin boards through Google. Due to the exponential increase in the number of threads, websites experience frequent crashes. 

Google has been notified of the worm's activities and has already taken steps to stop it from accessing the search engine. Said a representative, We are aware of the situation and have steps in place to defend against this issue. However, the sheer number of sites affected by the worm is showing just how challenging it is to stop its rampage entirely.

The authors of the PHP bulletin board system are set to release an upgrade to the system that will make it more resistant to the attacks by the worm. Website administrators across the spectrum are waiting eagerly for this update so they can restore their websites back to their original nature.

Ironically, this worm was named after the Santa Claus, the symbol of joy and happiness during the Christmas season. Instead of spreading cheer, the Santy worm has brought a clear disruption to the festive spirit.

Cybersecurity companies have been urging businesses and individuals to improve their online security measures. In these evolving digital times, it's essential more than ever, to take care of not just our physical security but also our digital one.

The Santy worms unwelcome visit once again underscores the risks inherent in our interconnected virtual world. It serves as a stark reminder that the web is not just a network of webs, but also a potential highway for digital malevolence. This Christmas, the urgent call clearly is to shield businesses and personal digital estates by taking cyber threats seriously.

As the world becomes increasingly digital, the environmental impact of our technology use is becoming a growing concern. Computers, in particular, are a significant contributor to electronic waste and energy consumption. However, there are ways to make your computer usage more environmentally friendly. 

Firstly, consider the energy efficiency of your computer. Many modern computers come with energy-saving features, such as sleep mode or automatic shutdown after a period of inactivity. Make sure these features are enabled to reduce your computer's energy consumption. Additionally, consider investing in a laptop rather than a desktop computer, as laptops typically use less energy.

Secondly, think about the lifespan of your computer. The longer a computer lasts, the less electronic waste is produced. Regular maintenance, such as cleaning and software updates, can help extend the lifespan of your computer. When it's time to upgrade, consider buying a refurbished computer rather than a brand new one. Refurbished computers are often just as good as new ones, but they generate less waste as they reuse existing components.

Thirdly, consider the materials used in your computer. Many computers contain harmful substances such as lead and mercury. Look for computers that are made with fewer harmful substances and more recycled materials. Some manufacturers even offer take-back programs, where they will recycle your old computer for you.

Fourthly, think about how you use your computer. Do you really need to print that document, or could you read it on screen? Can you reduce your data usage by downloading files rather than streaming them? Small changes in behaviour can have a big impact on the environmental footprint of your computer.

Finally, consider the end of your computer's life. When it's time to dispose of your computer, don't just throw it in the bin. Many components of a computer can be recycled, and there are many organisations that will take your old computer and ensure it is disposed of in an environmentally friendly way.

In conclusion, while computers are a necessary part of modern life, there are many ways we can reduce their environmental impact. By considering energy efficiency, lifespan, materials, usage, and disposal, we can all make our computers a little greener.

In a scintillating display of talent, Sam Yelling achieved a remarkable hat-trick at Cardiff's annual marathon, marking him as a rising star in British marathon running.

Taking place yesterday, the marathon saw Yelling battling adverse weather conditions and stiff competition, yet emerging victorious for the third consecutive year. The 28-year-old Royal Army officer completed the 26.2-mile course in 2 hours, 14 minutes, and 31 seconds -- 36 seconds faster than his closest rival.

Yelling, a Hampshire native, proved his world-class credentials with a faultless performance. He started strong, setting the pace in the throng of competitors, before striding ahead of them during the final stages of the race to retain his title.

"It's an incredible feeling," a visibly elated Yelling commented post-race. "This is the hardest race physically and mentally I've ever done, and to have won it three times now is just unbelievable."

His golden streak began back in 2019 and has gone unbroken since, marking Yelling as the first participant to achieve a hat-trick win in the history of the Cardiff Marathon. 

Hundreds of spectators lined the wet, cold streets to witness Yelling make history, their cheers echoing across the city. Yellings triumph is already causing a buzz in the international marathon circles, with many experts earmarking him as a potential Olympic contender for the impending games.

Yelling expressed his gratitude to his trainers and his family, who have supported him throughout his journey. "My family has been with me every step of the way," Yelling said, trying to hold back his emotions. "Their tireless support and encouragement have driven me to push my limits."

The Cardiff Marathon, Wales largest mass participation and multi-charity fundraising event, witnessed over 20,000 participants this year, from elite professional athletes to fundraising heroes running for causes close to their hearts.

Yelling's victory provided a significant morale boost to the organisers, athletes, and the spectators alike, showcasing the sheer determination and resilience of a true sportsman. His victory served to remind everyone that even in the most uncertain times, there is a steadfast spirit in people to push beyond their boundaries and achieve greatness.
Commenting on his future plans, Yelling said, "This win has just strengthened my resolve. I aim to keep improving and make my mark at the Olympic level."

Senior Labour Party officials have denied reports that former Prime Minister Gordon Brown is being lined up to play a leading role in the party's campaign for the next general election. 

Rumours have been circulating in Westminster that Mr Brown, who led the party from 2007 to 2010, was being considered for a prominent role in the campaign. The speculation was fuelled by Mr Brown's recent high-profile interventions on issues such as Brexit and Scottish independence.

However, a senior Labour Party source told the BBC that there was "no truth" in the reports. "Gordon Brown is a valued member of the Labour Party and his views are always welcome," the source said. "But there are no plans for him to take a leading role in the election campaign."

Mr Brown, who served as Chancellor of the Exchequer under Tony Blair before becoming Prime Minister, has largely stayed out of frontline politics since stepping down as Labour leader following the party's defeat in the 2010 general election.

In recent months, he has made a series of speeches and written articles on key political issues, leading to speculation that he was preparing for a return to a more active role in the party.

But the Labour source said: "Gordon Brown has always been clear that his role now is to contribute to the debate on the big issues facing our country, not to return to frontline politics."

The denial comes as Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer prepares to launch the party's campaign for the next general election, which is due to take place in 2024.

Sir Keir has faced criticism from some quarters of the party for his leadership style and policy direction, leading to speculation about potential challenges to his position.

However, the Labour source dismissed suggestions that Mr Brown was being lined up as a potential successor to Sir Keir. "There is no leadership contest in the Labour Party and there are no plans for one," the source said. "Our focus is on holding the government to account and preparing for the next general election."

Mr Brown has not commented on the reports.

The Liberal Democrats have launched a dedicated manifesto focusing on women's rights and gender equality. The party's leader, Sir Ed Davey, unveiled the manifesto, which outlines a series of policies aimed at addressing the gender pay gap, improving women's health and safety, and promoting women's participation in politics.

The manifesto, titled "Empowering Women", includes a commitment to introduce a law requiring companies with more than 250 employees to publish data on gender pay gaps. The Lib Dems also pledge to extend the use of gender pay gap reporting to include data on race and disability.

In terms of health, the party promises to tackle inequalities in women's healthcare, with a particular focus on improving access to mental health services. The manifesto also includes a commitment to end period poverty by providing free sanitary products to those in need.

On the issue of safety, the Lib Dems propose to invest in services that support victims of domestic abuse and sexual violence. They also plan to introduce a new law to tackle online abuse and harassment, which disproportionately affects women.

The manifesto also addresses the underrepresentation of women in politics. The Lib Dems pledge to ensure that at least 40% of their parliamentary candidates are women. They also propose measures to support women in leadership roles, such as offering training and mentoring programmes.

Sir Ed Davey said, "This manifesto is a comprehensive plan to address the systemic inequalities that women face in our society. We believe that by empowering women, we can create a fairer, more equal society."

The unveiling of the women's manifesto comes as the Lib Dems seek to position themselves as the party of equality ahead of the upcoming general election. However, critics argue that the party needs to do more to address gender inequality within its own ranks, pointing out that only a third of Lib Dem MPs are women.

The party's women's spokesperson, Christine Jardine, defended the party's record on gender equality, saying, "We are committed to doing everything we can to promote women's rights and gender equality. This manifesto is a clear demonstration of that commitment."

The Lib Dems' women's manifesto is thought to be the first of its kind in British politics. It remains to be seen how these proposals will resonate with voters, and whether they will help the party to make gains in the upcoming election.

Chinese aviation company, China Aviation, is currently seeking a rescue deal to reduce its potentially crippling debt burden, according to industry insiders. The move comes after a series of financial struggles caused by the global slowdown in air travel and decrease in aircraft demand due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

The national carrier has approached several local and international financiers for assistance, including the Chinese government and a consortium of global investment banks. Specific details of the rescue deal have not yet been disclosed but are believed to include debt restructuring options and a potential equity injection. 

The aviation industry worldwide has been hit hard by the pandemic and China Aviation is not an exception. Although domestic travel is gradually recovering in China, international travels are still significantly down, which greatly affects the profitability of aviation companies. 

"Faced with a dramatic decrease in revenue, we are looking at a range of measures, including financial restructuring and seeking external investment," says a spokesperson for China Aviation. He further added that the company is "working tirelessly to protect the interests of our shareholders, staff, and customers as we navigate through the current turbulent times."

According to market analysts, China Aviation's situation reflects the broader difficulties faced by the global aviation sector. The International Air Transport Association (IATA) predicts that airlines worldwide will lose more than $300bn this year, and many will not survive without state-backed rescue deals. 

The airline's business partners, aircraft manufacturers Airbus and Boeing, have also been deeply affected by the crisis, with both companies experiencing a decrease in orders as airlines adjust their business plans to current demand.

Negotiations and discussions with potential investors are ongoing, but no definite agreements have been reached yet.  The company assured that further announcements will be made when there are significant developments. The Chinese government, which has a significant stake in China Aviation, has yet to comment publicly on the matter.

Many airlines are in survival mode as they reduce operations and furlough staff to cut costs. Companies are forced to consider innovative solutions, alliances, and mergers to survive the financial losses caused by the pandemic. The rescue deal for China Aviation is crucial and it needs to be finalized swiftly to prevent further financial distress for the struggling company.

British filmmaker Arran Alexander has suffered a setback as his much-anticipated movie recorded a disappointing box office report in its opening week.

Alexander's latest venture, 'Distant Warriors', opened last weekend to lacklustre audience response and managed to rake in only 1.5 million in the UK. This dismal performance is significantly below the 6 million it grossed in the US during the same period.

The film, budgeted at an estimated 35 million, is a historic epic portraying the world of medieval knights. Despite an ensemble cast featuring A-list celebrities and extensive promotions, 'Distant Warriors' failed to strike a chord with the viewers.

Critics have cited the screenplay's pacing and heavy reliance on historical accuracy over character development as some of the main reasons for the film's underperformance. Veteran film critic Martin White stated, "The film lacked the human touch. While the sets and costumes are stunning, the narrative falls flat."

This is a significant setback for Arran Alexander, known for his previous commercial hits like 'Intrepid' and 'The Last Heiress.' To recover the production and marketing costs, 'Distant Warriors' needs to perform exceptionally well in global markets, which remains uncertain.

Following the disappointing response at the box office, Alexander issued a statement thanking his team for their hard work and dedication. "I am proud of 'Distant Warriors' and fully stand by our work. We have received positive feedback from the audiences who have seen it. We hope that more people will see its value as time goes on," he said.

It is worth noting that Arran Alexander's films have historically taken time to pick pace and have displayed a consistent trend of gaining traction following initial slow starts. However, the director has admitted that the film industry's unpredictability makes it tough to determine whether this trend will hold for 'Distant Warriors.'

In the light of strong competition from other releases during the same period, the performance of 'Distant Warriors' in the coming weeks will be crucial in determining parameters of success for this latest release from the acclaimed director. The film's fate may significantly influence Arran Alexander's future ventures and the expectations that industry and audiences have of him.

For now, the world of film awaits to see if this cinematic narration of medieval valour can rebound from its initial disappointment and eventually find its footing at the domestic and global box office.

Indian tennis champion, Sania Mirza, has created history by becoming the first Indian woman to win a Women's Tennis Association (WTA) event, further underlining her unique status in the nation's sport.

Mirza, 34, secured the historic title at the Monterrey Open in Mexico, partnering with her Ukrainian teammate, Nadiia Kichenok. She defeated the second-seeded duo of China's Zhaoxuan Yang and Brazil's Lusa Stefani to clinch the doubles title, sealing a resounding victory for India on the international tennis circuit.

Overcoming multiple hurdles, including injuries and a forced break due to motherhood, Mirza's triumphant return to the court has been nothing short of inspiring. The victory was even more poignant, coming just over two years since her return to the professional tennis circuit.

Despite the pandemic disrupting the tennis calendar significantly, Mirza's unwavering focus and resilience have ensured that she continues her ascent up the global tennis ranking. Her performance and recent success underscore her competitiveness and dedication to the sport she has been playing since she was six.

Mirzas accolades do not stop at being India's highest-ranking female tennis player and the first Indian to break into the top 50 in the WTA rankings. She has also been awarded the prestigious Arjuna Award and Padma Shri by the Indian Government for her outstanding achievements in tennis.

Her historic win in Monterrey catapults her into a league of her own, providing a beacon of hope and inspiration for young, aspiring athletes in India. It is a monumental win that serves as a testament to her talent, determination, and resilience.

The victory also cements her reputation as one of the greatest trailblazers in Indian sports history. Her success is expected to pave the way for India's future generation of tennis players, inspiring them to pursue their dreams in the sport.

Sania Mirza's historic win reaffirms her status as one of the top sportswomen in the world. As the nation celebrates this landmark victory, it serves as a reminder of the immense potential and prowess India possesses in the field of sports.

News Corp, a global media company, has announced its intention to acquire Fox for a staggering $5.4 billion, in a move that could significantly reshape the global media landscape.

Rupert Murdoch's News Corp made the takeover bid for the broadcasting and entertainment conglomerate, upping the ante in an industry grappling to consolidate amidst the rapidly changing digital environment. The deal grossly expands News Corp network, which already includes brands such as The Wall Street Journal, New York Post, and The Times.

The proposed acquisition offers further evidence of Mr. Murdochs desire to consolidate his global news and entertainment media empire. Fox's vast portfolio includes numerous television broadcasters in various countries, movie studios and cable networks.

A merger of this magnitude would provide News Corp with a more diverse array of media assets, enhancing its dominance in the industry. It would also mark the first time that News Corp has ventured into the broadcasting sector on such a large scale.

The deal represents another potential reshaping of the media industry at a time when traditional media companies are seeking to bolster their offerings in the face of increasing competition from digital platforms.

This is not the first time Murdoch has attempted a massive deal of this kind. In 2017, News Corp made a failed bid to fully acquire Sky News, an attempt that ended due to regulatory concerns and competition.

Neither Fox nor News Corp immediately commented officially on the offer. The final decision will likely rest with regulators who will have to review the potential impact of the deal on competition.

Analysts are speculating on what potential regulatory hurdles might lay ahead. Given the size and potential impact of this deal on the global media industry, their decision will be closely watched.

The proposed deal, if passed through regulators, would potentially be the largest-ever acquisition in the media industry, highlighting the massive consolidation taking place as companies seek to adapt to the increasingly digitized media landscape.

Industry experts argue that the deal could potentially limit the degree of competition in the market, leading to increased prices for consumers. On the other hand, they also indicate that the merger could lead to greater innovation and diversity in programming and content as conglomerates attempt to attract larger audiences. 

News Corp shareholders appeared to welcome the news, with shares in the company rising by 1.4% at the close of trading. Meanwhile, Foxs stock also experienced a slight surge. Consequently, this could be a significant development for investors in both beasts of the global media industry.
