I am writing this to share my experience of getting testosterone (T) through Planned Parenthood and hope it helps those who are considering it as an option. Planned Parenthood is an organization that offers many different services, including hormone replacement therapy (HRT) for transgender individuals. I started my T journey a couple of months ago and here's how it went.

I first went to Planned Parenthood around August last year for a general check-up and expressed my interest in starting T. The nurse I spoke with was very understanding, professional, and answered all of my questions honestly. I was informed that PP follows an informed consent model, meaning I didn't require a letter from a therapist or a long evaluation process to start HRT.

Fast forward to about a month later, I had a phone consultation where a nurse asked me various questions about my health, mental state, and reasons for wanting to start T. She also made sure that I understood the potential effects and risks of T.

About a week after the phone call, I was scheduled for an in-person appointment where they took my blood for lab work. I was also given an opportunity to ask more questions and go over the potential effects of HRT again. The staff was very patient, kind, and understanding throughout this process.

Once my lab results came back, I was called in for my first T shot appointment. Since then, I have been going back to PP every 2 weeks for my shots. They've walked me through the process of self-injecting, but I'm not quite comfortable doing it on my own yet.

Billing was pretty transparent. I was told beforehand how much each appointment would cost. They also offer options for those without insurance or with financial constraints. 

Overall, my experience has been quite positive. The staff I dealt with were respectful and supportive. They did a great job explaining everything and making me feel comfortable. I was initially worried about going to Planned Parenthood for this, as I wasn't sure about their knowledge or acceptance of trans individuals, but those fears quickly vanished after my first visit.

In a nutshell, if you're considering starting testosterone and have access to a Planned Parenthood, it can be a great option. It might be different for each PP center, but I believe most of them follow the informed consent model which makes HRT quite accessible.

I hope this post can provide some insight for those seeking information on this topic. Everyone's experience will differ, but positive stories can sometimes be harder to find, so I wanted to share mine.

I don't know. All I know is that I'm tired. I'm tired of hating myself for things I can't change. I'm tired of living in the past. I just want to move forward, but I don't know how.

I've been thinking about this mod concept for some time now, and I believe it could seriously enhance the Fallout gameplay experience. So, here are my thoughts:

What if we could merge the teleportation functionalities of two unique locations - Mothership Zeta and Big MT (Old World Blues DLC)? This approach would mean escaping the frustration of being essentially 'stuck' in either of these locations, while simultaneously adding a cool piece of tech to our gameplay.

For context, once you reach Mothership Zeta in Fallout 3, you're essentially confined to the spacecraft with no fast travel option back to the Wasteland until you complete the main quest. This is also the case with Big MT in Fallout: New Vegas' Old World Blues DLC. Players would definitely benefit from an integrated teleportation system interconnecting these two places, saving time and making it more convenient.

I envision this modification to function something like this:

1. The instant you step into Mothership Zeta/Big MT, you'd be given a handheld device (or incorporated into the Pip-Boy) that would allow you to come and go as you please.
2. In Mothership Zeta, it could be something like a salvaged alien tech, and in Big MT, assuming the innovative, high-tech theme, it could be a newly coded feature in your Pip-Boy.

This way, interconnecting two of the game's most intriguing locations would allow for a great balance between exploration and freedom.

Of course, this is just an idea I've had floating around in my head. I admittedly have no modding abilities, but if anyone here is interested in developing this, feel free to run with it!

Would love to hear thoughts, suggestions and potential improvements on this idea!

Hello everyone,

I wanted to share a little bit about my experience as a young mom. I had my first child when I was just 19 years old. It was a challenging time, as I was still figuring out who I was and what I wanted in life. I had to grow up quickly and learn how to balance my own needs with the needs of my child.

Fast forward to now, I'm 24 and I have three beautiful children. I've learned so much over the past few years and I wouldn't change my journey for anything. However, I've noticed that there's a lot of stigma attached to being a young mom. People often assume that I'm irresponsible or that I don't know what I'm doing. 

I want to challenge these stereotypes. Yes, being a young mom is hard. But it's also incredibly rewarding. I've learned so much about myself and about life through raising my children. I've become more patient, more compassionate, and more resilient. I've also learned how to prioritize my time and manage my finances effectively.

I'm not saying that everyone should become a young mom. But I do think that we need to have more respect and understanding for young moms. We're doing the best we can in a difficult situation. And we're raising the next generation of leaders, thinkers, and doers.

So, to all the young moms out there, I see you. I appreciate you. Keep doing what you're doing. You're doing an amazing job. And to everyone else, let's show a little more kindness and understanding to the young moms in our lives. They deserve it.

Thanks for reading.

I'm sitting here in the waiting room, pressed into an uncomfortable chair, trying to find words to write this post. The idea of going back to the hospital is terrifying me. Not because I'm scared of needles or tests but primarily due to a sense of dj vu, the recollections of the previous visit are haunting me. 

A few months ago, I had my first encounter with a life-threatening situation. An emergency appendectomy brought me under the harsh lights and the cold atmosphere of the operation theatre. The experience was traumatic, to say the least, and the recovery period even more so. The sterile smell of the hospital, the echoing beeps of the machines, and the antiseptic white all around me had become my temporary reality. But I pulled through.

Cut to the present, I've been feeling unwell again. Routine tests and a follow-up consultation later, here I am, waiting for my name to be called out, mentally preparing to relive the ordeal. Ironically, this hospital, which serves as a beacon of hope for many, sends chills down my spine every time I think about it.

I think part of whats frightening me is the uncertainty  not knowing whats wrong this time makes my imagination run wild. I'm caught in this loop of anxiety and fear, the thoughts of "what-ifs" and "maybes" continually swirling in my mind, making it hard for me to think clearly.

I'm writing this post not to scare anyone but to share my apprehensions. I know there are many out there who share this fear, this dread of hospitals. I also know there are others who think this fear is irrational. But until you've lived it - until you've had your life changed in minutes by a diagnosis or a surgical procedure, it's tough to understand that fear.

And still, despite the fear, despite the anxiety, life goes on. We pull our bravery from somewhere deep inside and face what we must. I'm doing the same - inhaling a deep breath, taking one step at a time, and keeping faith that this too shall pass. We are stronger than we think. Just wanted to put my thoughts into words and connect with others going through similar experiences. Thanks for reading.

Has anyone here tried the Bernese method followed by a rapid taper? How did it go for you? Did you experience any withdrawal symptoms? How did you manage them? Any advice or personal experiences would be greatly appreciated. Thanks in advance!

So I've been playing Camp Buddy for a while now, and as much as I love the game and the storyline, it's starting to take a toll emotionally. It may sound silly to some, but it's become a source of depression for me.

The game highlights youth, friendship, and innocent love, three things I feel like I've missed out on in my own life. I spent my adolescence being incredibly introverted, battling my own issues, and now being an adult with responsibilities, I feel like I've missed out on those carefree days.

Each character in the game has their own unique story and background, some of which resonate with my own personal experiences, amplifying the feeling of longing and regret. It makes me wish I could turn back time, be a bit more courageous and out-going, make more friends, maybe even find love.

Sure, it's just a game. But games, books, movies - they're meant to evoke emotions, right? The characters and their stories seem too real at times, reminding me of my own past and the choices I've made.

I appreciate the designers for their beautiful work and creating such endearing characters. I'm sure for many, the game brings an immense amount of joy. But for me, it's a painful reminder of my youth gone by and opportunities lost. 

Just felt like pouring out. Have any of you felt the same way about a game?

I've been using my AirPods with my iPad for a while now, and for the most part, they've been great. However, I've recently run into a rather silly problem that's been driving me nuts.

Every time I connect my AirPods to my iPad, they work perfectly fine for a few minutes. But then, out of nowhere, the audio just cuts out. The AirPods are still connected according to the Bluetooth settings, and the battery isn't low or anything. The audio just... stops. 

I've tried disconnecting and reconnecting them, resetting the AirPods, resetting the iPad's network settings, and even tried them on my iPhone to see if the problem persists (it doesn't). I've also checked for any software updates, but everything is up to date.

I've seen a lot of people praising Apple's ecosystem for its seamless integration and the whole "it just works" philosophy, but this issue has been anything but seamless. It's incredibly frustrating, especially when I'm in the middle of watching a video or listening to music and the sound just disappears.

Has anyone else experienced this problem? Any suggestions on how to fix it? I love my AirPods and I really don't want to have to replace them, but this issue is making them almost unusable with my iPad. Any help would be greatly appreciated!

I've been feeling this way for quite some time now. It's like I'm speaking a different language that no one else understands. I try to express my thoughts, feelings, and ideas, but it seems like they just fall on deaf ears. It's not that people are intentionally ignoring me or dismissing what I say, it's just that they don't seem to truly understand where I'm coming from.

I've tried to explain my perspective in different ways, using different words, metaphors, and examples, but it's like there's a disconnect somewhere. It's incredibly frustrating and isolating. I feel like I'm on an island all by myself, shouting into the void.

I'm not sure if it's because my thoughts are too complex, or if I'm just not good at expressing them. Maybe it's a bit of both. I just wish I could find someone who truly gets me, who can understand my thoughts and feelings without me having to explain them in painstaking detail.

I've been working in a small boutique jewelry store for a couple of years now. We sell a variety of unique, handcrafted pieces that cater to a wide range of tastes. However, not everyone appreciates the artistry and craftsmanship that goes into our products.

Yesterday, a woman walked into the store and immediately started criticizing one of our necklaces on display. She loudly declared it to be the "ugliest thing" she'd ever seen. I was taken aback, but I maintained my professionalism and asked her what kind of jewelry she was looking for.

She proceeded to describe a very generic, mass-produced style of necklace that you could find in any department store. I politely informed her that we didn't carry that kind of jewelry, as our focus was on unique, artisan pieces. She huffed and left the store in a hurry.

I was a bit shaken by the encounter, but it also made me realize something. Our store may not be for everyone, and that's okay. We cater to a specific clientele who appreciate the uniqueness and artistry of our pieces. And while it's never pleasant to hear negative comments about our products, I'm proud of the work we do and the beautiful pieces we create.

So, to anyone who's ever been criticized for their taste or style, remember this: beauty is subjective. What one person finds ugly, another may find beautiful. Don't let anyone else's opinion diminish your love for what you find beautiful.

I'm going to start this off by saying that I understand, now, the severity of my actions. I see why he left. I don't blame him.

I was diagnosed with Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD) a few years ago. It explained much of my volatile behaviour, my intense fear of rejection or abandonment, my impulsivity, and the rage I would fly into for what seemed like the smallest of infractions. After diagnosis, I made a promise to myself and my boyfriend that I would find a way to manage it. He supported me in this, always believing that I could change.

But I didn't. I slipped into a routine of old habits. I used my illness as an excuse for actions that were inexcusable. His day was fraught with land mines - saying the wrong thing, not saying enough, being too distant or too close  all potential triggers for my anger, my fear, my insecurity. He walked on eggshells around me, always on high alert, always anxious. I was the abuser, exercising power and control in the most destructive of ways.

He gave me chance after chance to change, to get help, to acknowledge the damage I was doing to him and our relationship. But I was blind to it. I let myself believe that it was him causing my behaviour, not my BPD, not me. It was easier to shift the blame, but I now see how wrong I was.

Now he's gone. He broke up with me two weeks ago. I can't bear the guilt, the shame, the thought of having pushed away the one person who loved me in spite of myself. I feel lost and hopeless and part of me just wants to disappear, to not exist anymore.

I don't really know where I'm going with this post. Maybe I just want to say it out loud, in writing, format it into reality. Yes, I screwed up. Yes, I was abusive. Yes, I drove him away. Or maybe it's a plea for help, a desperate cry into the void of the internet. I don't really know. I just know that I cant bear the pain and loneliness. I want it to stop. Don't know how to start picking up the pieces of my shattered self. 

I suppose I'm welcoming advice  on dealing with loss, guilt, self-blame, regret. I want to change, but I also don't know how to forgive myself for the hurt I've caused. For anyone who lives with BPD,

I've been thinking about this hypothetical battle for a while now and wanted to get some opinions from fellow Dragon Ball fans. 

On one side, we have Vegeta with Super Saiyan Blue Evolution (SSJBE) and Kaioken x20. This form is a significant power-up from the standard Super Saiyan Blue, and the addition of Kaioken x20 would theoretically multiply his power, speed, and senses by 20 times. 

On the other side, we have Goku in his Ultra Instinct form. This form is characterized by a calm, focused state of mind that allows for incredible speed and reflexes. Goku's movements become automatic, dodging and countering attacks without conscious thought. 

So, who do you think would win in a fight? 

Would Vegeta's raw power and speed be enough to overcome Goku's heightened senses and reflexes? Or would Goku's Ultra Instinct form allow him to dodge and counter all of Vegeta's attacks, eventually wearing him down? 

I'm interested to hear your thoughts and theories on this. Let's keep the discussion friendly and respectful.

In statistics, accuracy variables are often squared for a number of reasons. The primary reason is to eliminate any negative values that can occur due to the difference between the predicted and actual values. This is particularly important in models where the absolute value of the error is more significant than its direction.

Squaring the accuracy variables also emphasizes larger errors. This can be useful in many scenarios where larger errors are more costly and thus, should be minimized more aggressively. For example, in financial forecasting, a larger error could lead to significant financial loss, so it's more important to reduce these larger errors.

Another reason is that squaring makes the mathematics easier when it comes to calculus and finding minimum or maximum values. It allows for the use of derivative-based methods in optimization.

Lastly, squaring the accuracy variables can make the distribution of errors more normal (Gaussian), which is a desirable property in statistical modeling as many statistical techniques assume that the errors are normally distributed.

However, it's important to note that squaring isn't always the best approach. It can overly penalize large errors, and in some cases, other methods like taking the absolute value might be more appropriate. It really depends on the specific context and the nature of the data you're working with.

Okay, so I am currently 7 months pregnant with my first child. I always thought pregnancy would make me feel ugly and unattractive due to the inevitable weight gain and body changes, but boy was I wrong.

I'm so done trying to excuse my dad's behavior. I've spent years trying to convince myself that he is a "good person", that he has his own struggles and hence the flaws. But today, I realized, it's not the struggle that defines him, it's his actions, his words, his decisions that are incredibly hurtful and unjust.

For as long as I can remember, I've always lived under this fear of doing or saying something that might upset him, not because I respected him, but because I was scared of him. He has this knack of making people feel insignificant, guilty for errors that are not even theirs. He dominates, manipulates and belittles, then hides behind the cloak of being a provider, a protector and a father.

I have tolerated his emotional, sometimes physical, abuse for years, trying to convince myself that it was just his way of showing love and that he didn't know any better, but no more. Tonight, I finally stood up to him, to his tyranny. He was demeaning my younger sibling for not being good at maths, something that he was struggling with. That was the last straw. I stood up not just for my sibling, but for myself, for my mother, for everyone who ever felt undermined by him.

Everyone reading this: I'm not saying it's easy. It's not. Standing up to someone who has held power over you for a significant part of your life, especially a parent, is incredibly difficult. But its essential for your mental health and well-being. Just because they are a parent doesn't give them a free pass to treat you poorly. And you don't have to accept it either. You deserve love, respect, and kindness. Don't let anyone convince you otherwise.
Sorry, but I can't assist with that.

I hope everyone had a peaceful Easter Sunday. Mine was a bit of a rollercoaster, to say the least. 

My family has always been deeply religious. We've been attending the same church for as long as I can remember. Every Sunday, without fail, we'd all pile into the car and head to the morning service. It was a tradition, a cornerstone of our family life. 

This Easter Sunday, however, something changed. 

We were all sitting around the dinner table, enjoying our Easter meal when the topic of church came up. My parents, usually the most devout among us, seemed... different. They were hesitant, almost uncomfortable. 

Then, out of nowhere, my dad said, "We've been thinking... maybe it's time for us to step back from the church a bit." 

I was stunned. I mean, this is the man who taught me how to pray, who instilled in me the importance of faith. And now he was suggesting they might leave the church? 

My mom chimed in, "We're not abandoning our faith, just reevaluating our relationship with the church. We've been feeling a bit disconnected lately, and we think it might be best for us to take some time to reflect on our beliefs outside of the church setting."

I'm still processing this. I respect their decision, of course, but it's a big change. It feels like a shift in the very foundation of our family. 

Has anyone else experienced something like this? How did you handle it? I'd appreciate any advice or insights you might have.

It's 3 am, and I cannot sleep. My mind is whirling with thoughts, but there's that one unwelcome memory that keeps seeping in  the lost chance.

Four years ago, I quit my job to launch a start-up with my best friend. We had passion, determination, and an innovative idea. However, we lacked experience, understanding of the market dynamics, and sufficient capital. The one year we spent trying to make things work was a rollercoaster ride with a harsh landing  we ended up in heavy debt and a broken friendship.

Fast forward to now, a successful competitor has just launched a similar product as ours. I cannot avoid thinking about what could have been if we had just held on a bit longer or if we had approached things differently.

I understand that dwelling on the past and on lost opportunities isn't right or helpful. But how is one supposed to just forget about the toils of hard work and dreams turned to dust?

Just reflecting on the fact that we had a potential million-dollar idea in our hands and let it slip away pains me a bit. I see this as my biggest failure.

I have learned a ton from this experience, which helps me perform better in my current job. But tonight I am just letting myself mourn the lost opportunity, the dream that could have turned into reality, the missed chance.

It's just one of those nights where it's okay to let these feelings surface, acknowledge them, understand them, rather than brushing them under the carpet. It definitely hurts, but I guess it's a good lesson that life goes on and I must too.

Has anyone ever experienced such a feeling? How do you deal with it without drowning yourself in regret or what-ifs? It's a difficult storm to weather, and I can use any advice you might have.

I've been a gamer for the better part of two decades, and I've seen the industry evolve in ways that are both exciting and deeply concerning. I'm not here to bash gaming as a whole, but rather to shed light on some of the issues that have been plaguing the industry and why I believe it's currently in a state of disarray.

Firstly, let's talk about microtransactions and loot boxes. These have become a staple in many games, especially those from AAA studios. While I understand the need for companies to make a profit, the implementation of these systems often feels predatory and exploitative. It's not uncommon for games to be designed in a way that encourages, or even necessitates, spending additional money to fully enjoy or compete in the game.

Secondly, the crunch culture in game development is a serious issue. Developers are often pushed to their limits to meet unrealistic deadlines, leading to burnout and a decline in the quality of the final product. This is not only detrimental to the developers' health, but it also affects the quality of the games we play.

Thirdly, there's a lack of innovation in the industry. Many studios seem to be playing it safe, sticking to tried-and-true formulas rather than taking risks and pushing boundaries. This leads to a market saturated with similar games, and it's disappointing for those of us who crave something new and different.

Lastly, the handling of intellectual properties is another concern. We've seen beloved franchises either mishandled or milked dry, with sequels and spin-offs that fail to capture the magic of the original games. This not only tarnishes the legacy of these franchises but also leaves fans feeling disillusioned.

In conclusion, while there are still many great games and passionate developers out there, these issues are casting a dark shadow over the industry. It's my hope that by bringing these problems to light, we can encourage change and ensure a brighter future for gaming.

Over the recent years, I've noticed a common term sprouting up in fitness and exercise discussions: tapering. Regularly used in the context of endurance sports, tapering seems to be gaining a lot of traction - if not importance - in different sporting and fitness regimen.

I understand that tapering incorporates a reduction in training intensity and volume, typically applied as a strategic move before major competitive events. However, what I want to understand more is: why is it gaining such popularity? What benefits does it offer, both mentally and physically, over regular training? Why are training schedules suddenly making generous room for this practice?

Also, many fellow athletes swear by different tapering 'schedules' or periods. Some recommend a few days, while others endorse a few weeks. Is there scientific backing for these varied periods, or is it subjective to individual capabilities and variability?

In essence, I am inviting a discussion and looking for insights into the merits and demerits of tapering. Also, I would love if someone can shed light on optimal periods and intensities of tapering that would be beneficial for most. 

Hoping to get enlightening responses from seasoned athletes, fitness enthusiasts, and health experts on this platform!

I've been pondering this for a while now and I thought I'd pop on here to see what other people might think. Many of us lean onto religion or spirituality in search of divine guidance, comfort, and peace; believing that a higher power, perhaps labeled as 'God', showers us with a form of unconditional love. However, from a more introspective standpoint, is it possible that what we perceive as 'Gods love' actually emanates from within us?

We often tend to anthropomorphize 'God' and there is nothing inherently wrong with this, but it can sometimes make us forget that divine entities, in most belief systems, are beyond human understanding. They do not possess human emotions or human limitations. So, could it be that what we are perceiving as Gods love traversing the conduits of time, space, and reality to reach us, might actually be our own innate ability to love ourselves unconditionally?

If this is a reality we accept, then shouldn't one of the ultimate goals of spirituality or religion be learning to fully love and accept ourselves, tapping into our infinite potential for self-love and compassion?

No disrespect is meant to anyone's believes here, and just to reiterate, these are just some personal thoughts Ive been grappling with that I wanted to share with the community. I'm interested in hearing your thoughts and opinions, whether they align with what I've said or come from a different viewpoint altogether.

I've been a part of this community for a considerable amount of time and have appreciated the insightful discussions and varied perspectives that are constantly brought to light here. However, lately something has been bothering me. Whenever a discussion is opened about women's issues, it seems that the default response is to create a mirrored thread for men's issues.

Now, I understand the necessity of inclusivity and equality, and I do not dispute that men's issues are also paramount and deserve their due attention. My grievance is not with the creation of such threads. It's just that it can be incredibly frustrating to see discussions about women's issues constantly countered rather than being taken on their own merit.

There's this implicit expectation that any conversation about women has to be 'balanced out' by a similar conversation about men. It feels like a knee-jerk reaction, a sort of "but what about men?" perspective, and it inadvertently downplays or dismisses the discussions we are trying to have about women's experiences.

Acknowledging womens issues doesnt take away from the serious issues that impact men. The constant pushback feels defensive and alienating. It can devalue the discussion and change the course of the conversation in a way that doesnt feel constructive.

We cannot gain a comprehensive understanding of gender issues if we keep switching the narrative. Some issues are predominantly faced by women, just like some are predominantly faced by men. We should be able to discuss each according to their dynamics, not as mirrored versions of each other.

It would be refreshing if we could sometimes just discuss matters pertaining to women and their plights without being met with an inevitable counter thread. We don't always have to apply the seesaw principle here. Sometimes, we just want to explore the topic at hand without causing a backlash or feeling like we're excluding others.

I hope we can resolve this issue to make our discussions and debates even more fruitful. Thank you for taking the time to read this and for any input you might have on the matter.

So, here's the situation: My co-worker (I'll call him Bob) has a habit of making offensive or derogatory comments, and every time he gets called out on it, he just brushes it off as "just a joke".

Yesterday, he made a sexist comment about another female colleague in the office (who wasn't present at the time). Everyone - two guys and me - kinda laughed awkwardly. I felt uncomfortable, and came right out and told him it's not a joke, it's disrespectful. 

Bob got defensive and told me I had no sense of humor, that I'm always ruining the 'fun'. People in the office now are divided. Some say I'm too sensitive, others stand by me saying it was a matter of respect.

I don't want to create tension or drama but I also don't want to let things slide and enable such behaviour. So, AITA here?

It's strange because I fully understand that I have no control over the condition I have, and that it's not my fault I have it. But sometimes I can't help but to feel more than just a twinge of shame about it. I guess society has woven this picture in my brain that physical health issues are acceptable, if not commendable to have overcome or be battling, but mental health issues? Thats different. Theres a near unconscious & pervasive stigma against it still.

I've been dealing with bipolar disorder and ADHD for a number of years now. It gets difficult to manage at times, and I've sought professional support for it, but I still feel sort of embarrassed to talk about it outside of my therapist's office or anonymous online spaces like this one.

Sometimes, I find myself dreaming of a world where anxiety disorders, depression, bipolar disorder, ADHD, etc. could be as normal to talk about as a broken bone or even chronic physical illnesses. I wish we didn't have to hide our struggles or our treatment plans. I wish I didn't feel like it's something to be ashamed of.

Do any of you feel like this too? I wonder how you deal with these feelings in our largely unreceptive world? Any coping mechanisms or tricks you have found to work for you?

So, I work in a local boutique known for its unique handcrafted jewelry. We have this policy wherein we cannot accept a return without receipt, as we need to establish that the purchase was indeed made from our store. 

Today, this middle-aged woman comes in fuming, practically throws a necklace at me and demands a full refund. She ranted about how your average, dime-a-dozen store would be ashamed to sell such a hideous piece. I'll admit, the obsidian pendant with intricate copper filigree work isn't for everyone, but it definitely isn't hideous.

Having worked here for a couple of years, I'm quite familiar with our inventory and couldn't remember anything specific about that piece. I asked her if she had a receipt. Predictably, she said she lost it. She was getting irate, so I calmly explained our return policy again. 

Entitled Customer: "But your necklace is ugly, and I want my money back."

Me: "I'm sorry, but without a receipt, we can't proceed with the return."

Then, she gave me the "Are you kidding me?!" look.

Out of curiosity, I double-checked our sales register, and voila! We never sold that specific necklace in the first place. Now, it's not unusual for a customer to get mixed up about where they bought something, but her attitude was another story.

Once I informed her of this, her face was all shades of red. Never seen someone high-tail it out of a store so fast.

Moral of the story: Not everyone has the same taste in jewelry. And, always keep your receipts!

I've been off of Kratom for 35 days now. Cold turkey. It hasn't been an easy journey, on the contrary, it's been a struggle each step of the way. But one thing I've come to realize, is that sometimes, we cling so hard to our nightmares not because we enjoy the pain, but it's primarily because it's all we know. We're comfortable with the familiar, the known, even if it's a cycle of suffering.

Upon realizing this, I've found it a bit easier dealing with this process of withdrawal and recovery. My addiction, albeit a nightmare, was a world I was familiar with. This new realm I'm entering, one of sobriety and self-control, is a foreign place that seems uncertain and threatens my comfort zone.

I finally understand the saying of the devil you know is better than the devil you don't. But is it? Wouldn't it be better to explore the unknown, step into new territories, and take control of our lives rather than keep enduring the pain of addiction simply because it's the path "we know and understand"?

Anybody else going through the same struggle, just remember, "if nothing changes, nothing changes". If you're scared of trying something new because of the uncertainty that comes with it, remember that staying in your comfort zone won't bring you any growth or progress.

Every day gets a little bit easier, and every day I'm learning to let go of my old nightmares. Let's not cling to this nightmare just because we are used to them. We are stronger than we believe and can overcome anything if we believe in ourselves. Stay strong, everybody. Keep going. Keep growing.

As a long-term member of this community, I feel deeply compelled to address an issue that's been nagging me lately. There's this growing trend  or misconception, rather  where people view vaping as a viable alternative to self-harm. I don't intend to promote either behavior. Both are harmful, but I reckon it's necessary to clear up this misinterpretation, which might inadvertently draw those seeking solace into another harmful practice.

Firstly, let's address self-harm. It's a complex issue, often reflecting deep emotional distress, and is something that should receive the attention of professional help rather than just a mere 'switch'. Therapy, medication, and other support systems are the real routes towards healing. Self-harm is never something that should be brushed under the carpet or addressed with temporary crutches.

Now for vaping. While yes, there is a growing body of evidence suggesting that it's less harmful than conventional smoking, it's most definitely not harm-free. Nicotine is still present in most e-cigarettes, which is a highly addictive substance. It can harm adolescent brain development and lead to addiction. 

Swapping self-harming for vaping is not a solution because both practices have negative consequences. They're simply different manifestations of harmful behaviors. Rather than swapping one damaging habit for another, the focus should be on fostering positive coping mechanisms and reaching out to professional help.

If you, or anyone you know, are thinking about self-harming or are seeking a less harmful option, I'd strongly suggest speaking to a professional, like a therapist, counselor, or even a trusted doctor. There are many online resources, hotlines, and apps available if you need immediate help. 

Remember, it's always okay to seek help. Battling these tendencies doesn't make you weak, but stronger. You deserve the support, love, and care needed in these tough times. We're a community here, we're here to support each other - but that must extend beyond this forum and into our real lives where professional resources can provide a ladder out of these harmful cycles.

I've been noticing a disturbing trend lately, both online and in real life, where individuals who are struggling with anorexia feel the need to shame or belittle others for their eating habits. I understand that anorexia is a serious mental health disorder and I empathize with those who are battling it. However, I believe it's important to address this issue as it's causing harm to others.

I've seen people being criticized for eating a slice of pizza, for enjoying a dessert, or even for just having a regular meal. This is not okay. Everyone has the right to enjoy food without being made to feel guilty or ashamed. Food is a necessity for survival and it's also one of life's great pleasures. No one should be made to feel bad for nourishing their body.

I understand that those with anorexia may have a distorted view of food and body image, but it's not fair or right to project these insecurities onto others. It's important to remember that everyone is fighting their own battles and we should aim to support each other rather than tear each other down.

If you're struggling with anorexia, I urge you to seek help. There are many resources available and professionals who can provide the support and treatment you need. But please, let's not make others feel bad for their eating habits. We should all strive to create a supportive and understanding environment where everyone feels comfortable and accepted, regardless of their relationship with food.

Sigh... I just need to vent this out and hope you all could sympathize or perhaps provide some advice.

For context, I'm a 24-year-old software engineer. I was making some pretty decent money for someone my age and had been with this promising startup for three years. I loved what I was doing, I was extremely skilled in the codes I wrote, and I respected my colleagues. In every sense, it was the perfect job, and I could see myself working there for years.

That was until yesterday.

We were planning to launch a new product, something we've been working on for a year. It was expected to sky-rocket the company into new heights and bring in a ton of revenue. But as the head of the development team, I had a lot of pressure on my shoulders.

Worryingly, as we were nearing the launch date - just a few days away - I found what appeared to be a minor bug. I thought it would be a quick fix, but panic set in as I realized how deep-rooted this bug was. This single issue could basically break the product we were releasing, making it essentially useless. 

I worked tirelessly - hours on end, I could barely see from exhaustion, much less think clearly. After three entire sleepless nights, I fixed the bug... or so I thought. Because in the process, Id made an even bigger mistake.

In my state of utter exhaustion, tinged with relief that I'd squashed the bug, I hurriedly pushed the new code to production without thoroughly testing it. 

When I woke up (or rather, rose from my desk where I'd fallen asleep), I found hundreds of emails and missed calls on my phone. 

It turns out, the "fix" I implemented was worse than the initial bug. It crashed our entire system and wiped out months of work. Not only had we missed the launch, but we also had lost so much critical data that it could potentially sink the company.

I've never felt so low in my entire life. 

I screwed up extremely bad, to the point of potentially ruining a multi-million-dollar company and upsetting countless people who counted on me. How do you even begin to bounce back from something like that? 

I guess I'm posting this as a cautionary tale to others. No matter how confident or skilled you are, always double-check your work, especially if a lot is riding on it. Always insist on thorough testing, no matter the pressure or deadlines. 

Anyway, thanks for reading

Growing up, my sister and I were raised in a household where love was a scarce commodity. Our parents were always too busy with their own lives, their jobs, their friends, and their hobbies. We were left to fend for ourselves, emotionally and sometimes even physically. 

I remember countless nights when we would sit in our shared bedroom, whispering stories to each other, trying to fill the silence that our parents left behind. We would dream about what it would be like to have parents who were present, who cared about our day, who hugged us and told us they loved us. 

As we grew older, we tried to find that love elsewhere. We sought it in friendships, in romantic relationships, in achievements and accolades. But no matter how much love we received from the outside world, it never seemed to fill the void left by our parents' neglect. 

I'm writing this post not to garner sympathy, but to reach out to others who may have experienced the same thing. I want you to know that you're not alone. That it's okay to feel hurt and angry and confused. That it's okay to grieve the love you never received. 

And most importantly, I want you to know that it's possible to heal. It's possible to learn how to love yourself, even if your parents never showed you how. It's possible to build healthy, loving relationships, even if you didn't have a model for it growing up. 

So if you're out there, feeling like you didn't get the love you deserved, know that you're not alone. And know that it's never too late to start healing.

I'm going to give it another shot, but right now, I'm feeling pretty disheartened. I really wanted to love this game, but so far, it's just not living up to my expectations. I hope it gets better, but right now, I just feel like crying.

Hello everyone,

To shed some light on my situation, Ive gone through many ups and downs over a span of 7 years. These years were filled with depression which seemed to constantly linger, no matter the changes I made in my life or the advice that was given to me by friends and family. It was like a shroud of darkness that refused to lift off me.

During those years, I dealt with the pressures of college and trying to balance my life amidst all the assignments, classes, and social events. The mental toll was immense, and at times, the load was unbearable. The journey was hard and there were moments where I felt like a total failure. 

On top of that, I had to face the ghosts of my past, particularly a turbulent childhood that left some deep emotional scars. Those memories haunted me and made it difficult to trust and form stable relationships. That led to a succession of relationships that mostly ended up enhancing my depression due to horrifying breakups.

Self-destructive behaviors became all too familiar for me. The number of times Ive exploited myself, both physically and mentally, is countless. There didn't seem much to keep me from falling into a loop of negative thoughts and actions, again and again.

But enough is enough. 

I realized that the kind of help I need is not something that a friend, a relative, or a partner can give. My healing process needs to be guided by a professional, someone who understands not only the science but also the art of healing the human mind. Hence, I am proud to share that I'm finally going to see a psychiatrist. 

The journey to improve myself, to discover the happy, healthy version of me, has finally begun. It's scary to think about the number of things I might have to confront during the therapy sessions, but I feel a sense of relief. Relief in knowing that I am taking the first real step towards a healthier me. 

I hope that sharing my story will encourage anyone else who is reading this and going through a similar situation, to seek help if you haven't yet. It's never too late to start improving and healing. Remember, its okay to ask for help. We are all a work in progress. 

Thank you for reading this far. Here's to progress, healing, and brighter days ahead!

I've been stewing over this for a while now and I just need to vent. I'm sure I'm not the only one who has experienced this, but it's been bothering me a lot lately. 

I'm talking about those situations where you're forced to make eye contact with someone, even when you're clearly uncomfortable. It's like some unwritten social rule that you have to look someone in the eyes when you're talking to them, but why? Why is it so important? 

I'm not talking about situations where it's necessary, like job interviews or important meetings. I get that. I'm talking about everyday situations, like casual conversations or even just passing someone in the hallway. 

I'm an introvert and I have social anxiety. Making eye contact is really hard for me. It makes me feel exposed and vulnerable. I feel like I'm being judged or scrutinized. It's just really uncomfortable. 

But people seem to take it personally if you don't make eye contact. They think you're being rude or that you're not interested in what they're saying. But that's not it at all. I'm just trying to protect myself. 

I wish people would understand that not everyone is comfortable with eye contact. It's not a personal slight. It's just a coping mechanism. 

Does anyone else feel this way? Or am I just overreacting? I'd love to hear your thoughts.

Certainly, it's easy to judge someone based on a single bad action they may have done. It's like a straightforward equation: action+outcome=judgment. However, I think life is a bit more complex than that and so are humans. 

Every action we make usually has a story behind it. Let's consider the criminal convicted for theft. Yes, their action was undoubtedly wrong and should face the consequences. But, what if necessity drove them to that path? Maybe they were desperate to feed a sick child, to pay mounting debts or because they lost their job in the middle of a pandemic? Are they pure evil or just victims of an unfortunate circumstance?

Or let's consider a person we know who may have lied, cheated or hurt someone. Of course, these actions are reprehensible. But what if they did it out of fear, pressure or because of untreated mental health issues? Again, it doesn't justify the action, but it provides some context. 

I'm not saying we should completely absolve people of their wrongdoings because of their circumstances or intentions. Each person should be accountable for their actions. However, I'm merely suggesting that perhaps we should look at the entire picture before passing judgment. Understanding the reasons behind a bad action doesn't make someone an advocate for it. It simply separates the person from the action and allows for empathy, growth and potential change. 

How do you all feel about this? Can you share a situation where you realized that there was more to someone's bad action than what met the eye?

I'm not sure if this belongs here, but I feel like I need to talk about this. I've been struggling with something for a while now and it's getting to the point where it's really affecting my mental health.

I'm a male victim of emotional and physical abuse, and for a long time, I've been hesitant to open up about it. There's this societal expectation that, as a man, I'm supposed to be strong and invincible, incapable of being hurt emotionally or physically, especially by a woman. Added to that, the fear of being laughed at, humiliated or simply not being believed makes it even tougher to break the silence.

The abuse happened in my previous relationship and it lasted for three years before I had the courage to leave. I was regularly manipulated, belittled, and physically assaulted. It's left me with some deep emotional scars that I'm still working through. Despite having removed myself from that situation, the echoes of it still affect my daily life, from my self-esteem to trust issues in new relationships.

The most crushing part about all of this, is the isolation. It's like I'm trapped in a cage made of fear and shame. None of my close friends or family members know about this, and it's eating me up inside. The stigma around male abuse victims is deafening. Most people are surprised to learn that men can be victims too, and this disbelief adds to the reasons why Ive remained silent.

I'm posting this here because I need someone to talk to. I know sharing this might not fix everything, but I think it's the first step in the right direction. I just want to stop hiding in my own shadow, and take steps toward healing.

If there's anyone else in this community who's been through similar experiences, words of advice and solidarity would be greatly appreciated. Thanks for taking the time to read this.

I'm writing this post today to shed some light on the situation of atheists in Bangladesh right now. Although Bangladesh is a constitutionally secular country, atheism and secular thought are topics that are unfortunately met with aggression, hostility and sometimes, outright violence in many parts of the country.

The rising tide of religious fundamentalism has cast a shadow on free thinkers, atheists, agnostics and secular bloggers. In the recent years, there has been an alarming spurt in incidents of violence - religiously motivated killings of those critical of religious fundamentalism and claimed atheists.

One could say that atheists in Bangladesh live in a state where they cannot openly express their beliefs or critique religion without a constantly looming fear of reprisal from extremist factions. Not just physical violence, but the threat extends to legal repercussions as well - "hurting religious sentiments" could lead to legal trouble, causing atheists to self-censor and stay silent.

On the positive side, there is a certain number of Bangladeshi atheists who are relentlessly fighting for secular space, but they do so at great personal risk. The creation and growth of anonymous online platforms have enabled these individuals to express their ideas and form a community, which seems to be growing.

In conclusion, while the situation is grim, there are brave people attempting to push for change. However, it's apparent that there is a long struggle ahead. The international community must prioritize pressuring the Bangladesh government to ensure the safety and freedom of speech for all its citizens regardless of their religious beliefs, or lack thereof.

The rule that employees must get a doctor's note for being out sick always seemed a bit excessive to me. If an employee is sick, we surely want them to rest and recover, not further exhaust themselves by dragging themselves to a doctor's office just to get a written excuse. And let's not forget about the fact that this potentially exposes others at the medical center to the illness, and puts additional strain on our healthcare system.

Not to mention that many folks might not have the time, money, or resources to see the doctor every time they have a minor illness that can be otherwise recovered from at home with proper rest and over-the-counter remedies. It seems like the healthcare system is already overburdened as is, without folks having to take time off work to make unnecessary doctor visits.

And lastly, I think it's also worth considering that making this requirement might discourage sick employees from even taking a day off. This potentially endangers others in the workplace and can significantly hinder recovery and productivity. It seems to me like it would be more beneficial to trust employees when they say they're sick and encourage them to stay home and recover instead. 

What are your experiences with this? Are there alternatives that could work better?

Anime endings have always been a contentious topic among fans. There are numerous instances where a seemingly great series is "ruined" for an individual viewer due to a poorly constructed or unsatisfactory ending. Unfortunately, a perceived pattern seems to be forming in the anime industry these days, causing growing concern among viewers.

For starters, there is an increasing tendency toward rushed endings. Stories that have been built up over two, three, or even four seasons are sometimes crammed into a single last episode. This often leads to a lack of characterization and development, inconsistencies, and plot holes. It feels as if the series was cut short due to time or budget constraints.

Secondly, there has been a noticeable increase in ambiguous endings. While not always a bad thing, when used excessively it begins to feel like a cheap cop-out or a way to leave things open for potential sequels. Many viewers are left feeling frustrated when they've invested time in a series only to be handed an ending that requires them to fill in their blanks.

Lastly, we've seen the rise of "shock value" endings. These endings seem to be designed primarily to get a reaction from the viewer rather than to serve the narrative or characters. They often involve dramatic plot twists or character deaths that feel forced or out of left field.

These three trends combined make it increasingly common for anime fans to walk away from a series with a bad taste due to the ending, despite having enjoyed the rest of the series. It's a worrying trend. An ending is the last thing viewers remember about a series, and a bad ending can tarnish the entire viewing experience.

That being said, its essential to remember that creating an ending that satisfies everyone is nearly impossible, and the judgement of an ending is incredibly subjective. Some may enjoy a more open ending which leaves them pondering, meanwhile, others find satisfaction in clear conclusions. However, recognizing patterns and avoiding repetition can ensure diverse, well-thought-out endings that don't get a barrage of hate.

So, what do you guys think about this trend? Have you noticed it as well, or do you think there is a different issue when it comes to anime endings? Let's discuss!

I am posting this to express my deep dissatisfaction and disappointment about the continuous stream of disrespectful memes concerning the recent passing of Prince Philip spreading across the internet. It's astounding to witness how my generation, gen z, which is well-known for advocating respect, inclusivity, and empathy, seems to blatantly disrespect such a grave and heartbreaking matter.

For those who may argue that it's just humor, I think it's crucial to understand that there is a line between humor and disrespect - a line that seems to have been ignored in this circumstance. The passing of Prince Philip, who served and represented the United Kingdom for several decades, deserves much more respect than what it is currently receiving, even from those who may not necessarily agree with or support the monarchy.

When did we become a generation that finds amusement in death? This recent event has made me question certain aspects of the online gen z community. I am aware that not everyone shares this perspective, and it's not meant as an attack towards anyone, but I believe that we need to promote more respect and kindness rather than using someone's death as a source of entertainment.

Humor and satire are subjective, and I completely understand that. However, a line must be drawn when it ventures into the territory of insensitivity and disrespect. This creates a toxic and harmful environment that erodes the core values of empathy and respect that we always advocate for.

We must remember that behind every meme, there's a real human being affected. Today it's Prince Philip, and tomorrow it may be someone we deeply care about and love. It's crucial to think twice before supporting, sharing, or creating something controversial like these memes. No one deserves to have their death made light of.

This is just a polite reminder for all of us, me included, to think before we act, to ensure that we do not turn into the insensitive, unempathetic people we claim not to be. Let's uphold respect, even for people who have lived lives vastly different from our own.

After years of being an active comic books fanatic, I've noticed that the topic of a characters' healing factor abilities is something of a contentious issue among many fandoms. Primarily, it seems, the debate revolves around the question of "Who has the best healing factor?"

A lot of comic book characters in both Marvel and DC universe have healing factors - the ability to recover from any injury at a superhuman rate. Wolverine, Deadpool, Hulk on Marvel's side, Superman, Doomsday, Wonder Woman on DCs side, the list goes on. While some heal from injuries or illnesses at a rapid pace, others can regenerate lost limbs or, at their most powerful, pull themselves back together from just a single cell.

However, the speeds and limits at which these characters can heal vary drastically. For example, a select few can recover from an injury instantly. Others take a more gradual amount of time. Theres also the question of the severity of the injury. Can they regenerate after being decimated? Or does it take a less traumatic event for their healing to kick in?

In my opinion, the healing factor shouldn't be the only parameter to measure their power. Characters are so much more than that. I also think its important to read into the specifics of these healing factors rather than focusing on the who would win in a fight debate. The healing factor ability also leads into discussions about immortality, ageing, resistance to toxins, etc.

However, I'm really interested in hearing what other fans think about this. Do you believe one character has a stronger healing factor than another? Do you consider fast healing as the highest power? Or in the end, do you think its all subjective depending on the writer at the time? Is there a need for more consistent rules regarding these abilities? Let's have a discussion! I really look forward to seeing everyones viewpoints.

So, I've been driving for Uber for about a year now and I've had my fair share of interesting passengers. But this one takes the cake. 

I picked up this guy from a local bar around 11 PM. He was dressed in the most flamboyant outfit I've ever seen - think Elton John meets Liberace. He was friendly and chatty, and we had a good conversation during the ride. 

As we approached his house, he suddenly turned to me and said, "Hey, why don't you come in for a drink?" I was taken aback. I've had passengers invite me for a coffee or a quick bite before, but never into their house. 

I politely declined, citing Uber's policy and my own personal comfort. He seemed a bit disappointed but didn't push it. He thanked me for the ride, gave me a generous tip, and went into his house. 

I drove away, feeling a bit weirded out but also amused. It was definitely one of the most memorable rides I've had. Has anyone else had similar experiences?

As a hardcore Dead by Daylight player, I have encountered the incessant problem of killers camping every single game, especially at the red rank, as solo survivors. As a solo survivor, this becomes particularly discouraging and frustrating, hindering any real progress in the game. 

Camping, for those unfamiliar, refers to the strategy used by killers where they remain near a hooked survivor refusing to leave, which denies survivors the chance to rescue and oftentimes ensuring their demise. It is somewhat perplexing and irritating considering we are supposed to be dealing with the 'cream of the crop' killers at this rank.

Frankly, this tactic doesn't challenge survivors' gameplay or strategy. It rather relies on exploiting an easy tactic to get a kill as opposed to genuinely earning it. This makes the game not only tedious, but weakening the overall competitive spirit the game is designed to enforce. 

The problem is further compounded by the inability of solo-survivor teams to communicate effectively. At lower ranks, or in survivor friends (SWF) groups, communication circumvents this by helping to distract the killer or applying pressure to the map elsewhere, forcing the killer to abandon the survivor. 

However, in higher rank play where many survivors are playing solo, lack of communication relieves the killer of these pressures. The inability to coordinate distraction tactics or split objectives often leads to a swift death for the hooked survivor and ultimately results in the killers victory.

The crux of the matter thus presented is how to deal with the camping issue especially for red-rank solo survivors? The developers need to think about this and come up with some possible solutions. It might be beneficial to implement stricter penalties for camping, or perhaps a better communication system for survivors?

It is understandable that every player has a different strategy and it's part of the fun trying to adapt and counteract. But applying such tactics can become frustrating for other players, turning the game into a monotonous sequence of events that can ultimately destroy the gaming community.

Open to thoughts, suggestions, or any possible solutions to this! Hoping the community can come together on this topic and induce some changes.

Hello everyone,

I'm reaching out to this community in hopes of finding some support and advice. My 2.5-year-old son was recently diagnosed with dilated cardiomyopathy. This has been a very difficult time for our family as we try to navigate this new reality.

For those who may not know, dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is a condition where the heart's ability to pump blood is decreased because the heart's main pumping chamber, the left ventricle, is enlarged and weakened. This diagnosis came as a shock to us, as our son has always been a very active and seemingly healthy child.

We are currently working with a team of pediatric cardiologists who are helping us manage his condition. He is on medication and we are monitoring his condition closely. However, the uncertainty of the situation is very stressful. 

I'm reaching out to see if there are any other parents here who have gone through a similar situation. Any advice on how to cope, what to expect, or resources that you found helpful would be greatly appreciated. We are also interested in hearing about any lifestyle changes that could potentially help manage his condition.

Thank you in advance for your support and advice. It means the world to us during this challenging time.

It was a decade ago, back in 2010 when I was a dumb, adventurous and invincible 20-year old. I had a penchant for psychedelics and one sunny afternoon found myself in possession of some good-quality acid. So, naturally, I decided to drop a tab and head over to the local park to enjoy the trip and experience the beauty of nature enhanced by the hallucinogen.

So, there I was lying on the grass, the trees above dancing and swirling, the sky turning a kaleidoscope of hues, and I was lost in my own little world. That's when a football spiraled through the air and landed beside me. I remember following its trajectory with childlike fascination. The kids playing nearby approached and asked if I could throw the ball back. My judgement and motor skills were questionable at that moment, but I agreed.

I picked up the ball and in my altered state of reality, missed the field by a good mile, and sent it straight through the windshield of a parked police cruiser. The sound of shattering glass brought me back to reality and I witnessed the uniformed officer emerging from a convenience store, staring at his demolished windshield.

I freaked out, to say the least, and irrational fear kicked in. The thought of explaining the situation to a police officer while tripping on acid was too daunting, so I did the only thing that seemed logical in the moment - I ran.

To my acid-drenched brain, it felt like I was outpacing a leopard but in reality, I must have looked like a drunk squirrel. I spent a good hour hiding, ducking and dashing through the town, till I finally reached the safety of my apartment. Heart still pounding, I peered from my window expecting to see squad cars and search lights, but all was calm outside. I spent the rest of the trip in terror, plagued by paranoia.

Obviously, running from the scene was an incredibly stupid and potentially dangerous decision. I was fortunate enough to not encounter the police again or cause harm to myself or others in my frantic state. In hindsight, I realize that tripping in a public place without a sober friend to guide me was a bad idea, a lesson learnt the hard way. 

Stay safe and responsible out there, folks. Psychedelics can be fun, but knowing your limits and understanding the implications of your decisions while under the influence is crucial.

Hello friends,

I hope this post finds everyone well. I am currently on day 6 of not taking opioids, a feat I never thought I would have the strength to do. The past few years have been a whirlwind of spiraling addiction and destructive behaviors and it was about time I held myself accountable. Today, as I sit here writing this post, I can see the light at the end of this long, arduous tunnel. 

The withdrawal symptoms kicked in on the second day. I experienced cold sweats, uncontrollable shaking, intense body aches, anxiety, insomnia, and several other frightening symptoms. The third and fourth days were much more challenging, with incessant vomiting and an intense craving for the drug I was weaning myself off. 

Day 5 was a blur. The physical symptoms seemed to lessen, but the mental toll was far from over. I found myself uncontrollably sobbing at times, feeling waves of guilt and regret for the path I had let myself go down. 

Today, day 6, I still feel an overwhelming urge to give in, to let this addiction take me back. But somewhere in me, a tiny voice says to keep pushing forward. I owe this to myself and I owe it to the people who love and believe in me.

Telling my story out loud (or rather, writing it for strangers to read) is not easy, but I believe that being open about our struggles is the first step towards overall healing and recovery. I want anyone else out there who is dealing with an addiction to know that you're not alone. Know that there's strength within you, even if you can't see it yet. Comment below if you need support or are also on this difficult journey. 

I will provide an update at the milestone of day 7. I don't promise it will get any easier, but with each day I feel a small victory in my fight against addiction. 

Stay strong everyone.

So, here's my story. I'm just an average person, living an average life. No significant achievements, no groundbreaking accomplishments. I live in a small town, working a regular 9 to 5 job. I have family and friends, but no thrilling travel experiences, no cool hobbies. I'm pretty much invisible on social media, with barely any followers or likes, apart from a close-knit group.

Some days, it stings, seeing people my age making it big, living the life I've only dreamt of. Other days, I'm content with my little bubble.

But lately, I've been feeling lost, as if I'm stuck in this void of nothingness. It's as if my identity and place in this universe have become insignificant. It's kind of scary, feeling like 'nobody', as if I don't make a difference in the grand scheme of things.

But then, isn't this what freedom is, in some twisted way? Having no identity or societal norm to live up to, no preconceived notions or hasty judgements, just me, in my raw form devoid of any labels. 

Is there anyone else out there who feels the same way? Can we cultivate this as our strength and just live our lives being 'nobodies'? Just throwing this out there to see if anyone else can resonate with these feelings. Any advice, thoughts, or shared experiences would be greatly appreciated. Let's have a conversation, shall we?

Being 'nobody' can sometimes be liberating, but more often than not, it's just... lonely. Is the loneliness worth the freedom? 

Maybe being 'nobody' is okay, or maybe it's not. I'm just trying to figure it out. Thanks for reading, fellow redditors.

I've been thinking a lot about the state of financial literacy among young people and I've come to the conclusion that we, as a society, are failing to equip our youth with the necessary tools to manage their finances effectively. 

From my own experience, I was never taught about budgeting, taxes, loans, credit scores, or investments during my school years. It was only after I graduated and started working that I had to learn all these things on my own. And let me tell you, it was a steep learning curve. 

I believe that financial education should start early on, ideally in high school or even middle school. This is the time when young people start to have their own money, whether it's from part-time jobs or allowances. It's the perfect opportunity to teach them about saving, budgeting, and making wise spending decisions. 

Moreover, understanding loans and credit scores is crucial for young adults who are considering going to college. They should be aware of the potential debt they could be taking on and how it could affect their lives post-graduation. 

Investing is another topic that should be introduced early on. With the power of compound interest, starting to invest at a young age can make a significant difference in one's financial future. 

In conclusion, I believe that financial education is just as important as any other subject taught in schools. It's a life skill that everyone needs, regardless of their career path. By teaching our youth about money management, we can set them up for a more secure and prosperous future.

As a teacher, I often find myself interacting with children on the autism spectrum in my classroom. Over the years, I've developed a few techniques to communicate effectively with them. Typically, I make sure to use easy-to-understand, simple and concise language and provide them with ample time to process and respond. I use visual aids whenever possible and I ensure a calm and soothing environment that doesn't overstimulate them. I try to alert them about changes in the routine beforehand. 

However, when I ask questions to autistic children, they sometimes get perplexed and don't respond. Other times, they might respond but not in the way I expected, at times due to misunderstanding the questions or sometimes because they approach the question from a different perspective.

One technique I've found successful is to give them choices instead of asking open-ended questions. For example, instead of asking "What do you want to do?", I ask "Do you want to draw or read a book?"

I was wondering if there is a better way to do this? Is there anything else I should keep in mind when asking questions to children on the autism spectrum to yield better responses? I'd love to hear from any autism specialists, parents of children with autism, or individuals on the spectrum. This is a learning process and your insights would be very valuable.

Hey folks, I wanted to share a recipe I found recently in Diablo II that I believe some of you might be interested in. By combining three perfect skulls, one rare item, and a Stone of Jordan in the Horadric Cube, you can craft a new item. This is extremely handy when you want to re-roll an item's stats for a potential better fit for your character.

For those who are new or need a refresher, the Horadric Cube is a quest item you can't miss when playing through Diablo II. It takes up only 2x2 squares in your inventory and can hold up to 12 objects inside of it, with each object taking up 1x1 square. The cube is used to combine items to create new items and can only be found in the Harem Level 2 in act two.

Now, here's how to use the recipe:

* 3 Perfect Skulls: You can mainly acquire skulls through killing monsters or through gem shrines when your character has no regular gems in his/her inventory.
* 1 Rare Item: Just find a rare item that you don't mind either losing or modifying. Because the recipe creates a new random roll of the item, you wont be able to predict the new modifier.
* Stone of Jordan: Rare and valuable, the Stone of Jordan ring can be found as a drop from any monsters starting at level 26. It can also be traded from other players. 

Once you have all the ingredients, simply load them into the Horadric Cube and manually activate the transmute power. The result will be giving the rare item new properties, which might turn out even better than the previous ones.

Remember, with every craft, there's a level of RNG involved. You may not always get the stats that you desire. Therefore, think through before using this recipe, specifically because the Stone of Jordan is quite rare.

Hope this post adds a bit to your Diablo II experience. If any of you seasoned veterans out there have additional tips or tricks about item combinations in the Horadric Cube, please feel free to share! Happy gaming!

After hours of research, gameplay, and comparative analysis, I am convinced that Turters--yes, this adorable little Shieldbug Sovereign--is the strongest character in the Xenoblade universe, even though initially this might seem like a trivial or laughable assertion.

Firstly, let's not ignore the fact that Turters actually carries Zeke and absorbs most of his attacks. Even though Zeke is known for his brute strength, Turters ends up taking a significant amount of damage for him. Despite that, it never shows any sign of fatigue or damage, which possibly suggests immense resilience and absorbing abilities.

Secondly, Turters' hidden strength lies within his tortoise-like shell. His shell is described in the game as "harder than any human-made material". It may not exhibit flamboyant combat skills, but its impenetrable defense mechanism is something that is hard to overlook.

The third point of consideration is Turters' mental strength, loyalty, and reliability. It does not matter how dire the situation gets or how strong the enemy is, it will always stick along with Zeke showing unwavering allegiance. This psychological strength cannot be understated, as it is often these attributes, rather than physical strength alone, that determines the outcome of a battle.

However, the most persuasive evidence comes in the form of the Turters summoning method. Turters, in a very low-key fashion, really controls Zeke. He maintains the ability to summon a "Blade", which suggests a power level typically only found among Drivers.

In conclusion, Turters, with its high durability, psychological resilience, and hidden control over one of the core characters, is unmistakably the strongest character in the Xenoblade series. Underrated for sure, but not to be underestimated!

Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to share my experience with Nexplanon, with the hope of seeking some advice or getting to know if others also encountered similar situations. I got my Nexplanon implant about six months ago. At first, everything seemed fine, and I was happy with my decision.

Initially, I didn't link these mood fluctuations to Nexplanon, assuming it was just due to work stress or personal issues. But lately, these mood swings have been more frequent and intense. So, I started to research about it and found that hormonal birth control can indeed cause mood swings.

I am not sure if what I'm experiencing is a common side effect or if it's extreme and something I should worry about. I can't help but wonder if anyone else has had a similar experience? Did your mood swings subside with time, or did you have to have the implant removed?

I've been seeing my therapist for about a year now and I can't even begin to express how much she has helped me. I was in a really dark place when I first started therapy. I was dealing with severe anxiety and depression, and I felt like I was drowning. I couldn't see a way out and I was scared.

From the very first session, my therapist made me feel seen and heard. She didn't judge me or make me feel like my feelings were invalid. Instead, she helped me understand why I was feeling the way I was and gave me tools to cope with my anxiety and depression.

Over the past year, I've made so much progress. I'm not completely "cured" and I still have bad days, but I'm in a much better place than I was a year ago. I've learned so much about myself and I've grown so much as a person. I've learned how to manage my anxiety and depression and I've learned how to take care of my mental health.

I honestly don't know where I would be without my therapist. She has been a constant source of support and guidance and I am so grateful for her. I can't thank her enough for everything she has done for me. She has truly changed my life for the better.

I just wanted to share this because I know there are a lot of people out there who are struggling and might be hesitant to seek help. I want you to know that it's okay to ask for help and that therapy can make a huge difference. Don't be afraid to reach out. You're not alone.
